Summary: An analysis of research suggests those who run regularly –– regardless of pace, distance, or amount of time –– are more likely to live longer and have a lower risk of cardiovascular disease or cancer.

Headline: Pain and neuromodulation: What’s all the “buzz” about?
Summary: Neuromodulation therapies use a targeted stimulus to help people manage pain. This can be in the form of an electrical stimulation device or a pump containing medication, either of which can be implanted in the body.

Headline: Cutting down on alcohol helps if you have atrial fibrillation
Summary: There is good evidence that the more you drink, the more likely you are to develop atrial fibrillation. A study found that people with afib who were willing to abstain from alcohol were less likely to have a recurrence.

Headline: The role of our minds in the avoidance of falls
Summary: In older people, the majority of falls occur when someone is standing or walking while also performing a separate cognitive or motor task. These tasks require more cognitive effort as we age, but focus and awareness can prevent falls from happening.

Headline: What’s new with the Nutrition Facts label?
Summary: The Nutrition Facts label that appears on packaged foods has been updated to provide consumers with more thorough information, and also to more accurately reflect typical consumption habits.

Headline: As coronavirus spreads, many questions and some answers
Summary: Readers have many questions about the new coronavirus (COVID-19). We have enlisted one of our experts on infectious disease to answer some of them.

Headline: New study compares long-term side effects from different prostate cancer treatments
Summary: Prostate cancer therapies are improving over time. But how do the long-term side effects from the various options available today compare? Results from a newly published study are providing some valuable insights. Investigators at Vanderbilt University and the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center spent five years tracking the sexual, bowel, urinary, and hormonal […]

Headline: Dopamine fasting: Misunderstanding science spawns a maladaptive fad
Summary: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in the body’s system for reward and pleasure. A recent trend has people avoiding stimulating activities in the belief that doing so allows the body to reset from being overstimulated, but the original idea has been misunderstood and wrongly applied.

Headline: Co-parent adoption: A critical protection for LGBTQ+ families
Summary: Establishing a legal relationship between parents and their children allows both parents to make care decisions. For LGBTQ+ families, this can be especially important. In some states, co-parent adoption, which offers broader protection than a state birth certificate, is available.

Headline: Puffing away sadness
Summary: The nicotine in cigarettes stimulates the nervous system, resulting in a mood boost. But does this mean that smokers will reach for a cigarette when they are feeling sad? Researchers found that sad feelings may cause some people to smoke.

Headline: Hands or feet asleep? What to do
Summary: It’s happened to all of us: a hand or leg temporarily “falls asleep,” usually from being in one position for too long. Why does it happen? Are there times when you should be concerned about it?

Headline: C. difficile (C. diff): An urgent threat
Summary: The bacteria known as C. diff has become a leading cause of infection among hospitalized patients. The infection is more common following antibiotic therapy, and it is challenging to treat because of a high relapse rate.

Headline: Five healthy habits net more healthy years
Summary: Following five healthy lifestyle habits has been shown to extend life expectancy. Better still, a recent study suggests the added years are more likely to be free of illness or disease.

Headline: Can light therapies help with bipolar disorder?
Summary: One approach to treating bipolar disorders is manipulation of the body’s circadian rhythms. A recent review of research found that such therapies may help, often in combination with medications and psychotherapy.

Headline: Good news for those with type 2 diabetes: Healthy lifestyle matters
Summary: Lifestyle changes have been shown to reduce the risk of a cardiovascular event, but can they also help those with diabetes? A recent study found a positive association between healthy lifestyle choices and reduced cardiovascular risk for those with type 2 diabetes.

Headline: What’s the best way to manage agitation related to dementia?
Summary: When people with dementia start exhibiting agitated behaviors, doctors often prescribe medications, but these have risks of serious side effects. A new study found that nondrug interventions were more effective than medications in reducing agitation.

Headline: African American and white men who receive comparable treatments for prostate cancer have similar survival
Summary: Last year, we reported on two studies showing that African American men respond at least as well as white men to prostate cancer treatments given in clinical trials. Nationally, African Americans with prostate cancer are more than twice as likely to die of the disease as their white counterparts, and that has fueled speculation that […]

Headline: Good for your teeth, bad for your bones?
Summary: Could an ingredient in toothpaste be harmful to your bones? Triclosan, an antibacterial agent, has been banned from soaps and hand sanitizers by the FDA, and researchers have found that women with the highest levels of triclosan in their urine had low bone density measurements.

Headline: When is a heavy period too heavy?
Summary: Girls and their parents often wonder when bleeding with a period is too heavy. It’s normal for periods to be irregular and occasionally heavy in the first few years after menstruation starts, but some signs of heavy bleeding merit a call to your child’s doctor.

Headline: Mind-body therapies can reduce pain and opioid use
Skin care shouldn’t be colorblind
Summary: Because skin color affects the presentation of skin conditions, dermatologists must consider skin color in making diagnoses. Because of this, people of color may want to seek out a dermatologist who understands their specific needs and concerns.

Headline: When should I be concerned about ringing in my ears?
Summary: Tinnitus is a term used to describe a ringing or noise in the ears. While not usually a serious medical condition, the distress it produces can often disrupt people’s lives. Understanding the condition and its symptoms will help determine how best to treat it.

Headline: What’s in a number? Looking at life expectancy in the US
Summary: Between 1959 and 2014, average life expectancy in the United States rose astoundingly by nearly a decade. Then it began declining. A recent report examining this situation raises tough questions about that unexpected change.

Headline: With a little planning, vegan diets can be a healthful choice
Summary: There is ample evidence to support the healthfulness of a vegan diet. However, those who choose vegan eating may not get enough of some nutrients unless they pay careful attention to their food intake, or choose to take supplements.
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: Coronavirus: What parents should know and do
Summary: It’s natural for parents to be worried about whether their children could be at risk from the novel coronavirus. While there is much that is still not known, common sense and simple public health precautions will help protect everyone.

Headline: Infertility the second time around
Summary: If you have a child and wish for more but are struggling with fertility issues, you may have many feelings and concerns. Here are some steps and strategies you may find helpful.

Headline: Newer skin cancer treatments improve prognosis for those with cutaneous melanoma
Summary: Though only about 1% of skin cancers are melanomas, they are responsible for 90% of skin cancer deaths. Recent advances in treatment options have improved survival rates for melanoma, but it’s still best to take preventive steps to protect your skin.

Headline: Be careful where you get your news about coronavirus
Summary: New information about the spread of coronavirus is coming at us seemingly every minute from many sources. But how much of this information is trustworthy? And which sources should you believe?

Headline: Hearing loss may affect brain health
Summary: Research into a possible connection between age-related hearing loss and brain function found that there is an association, with subjects 50 or older showing signs of cognitive decline even before reaching clinically defined hearing loss.

Headline: Food allergy, intolerance, or sensitivity: What’s the difference, and why does it matter?
Summary: Many people have experienced unpleasant symptoms related to food, but such a reaction does not necessarily mean that you have a food allergy. The symptoms could indicate a food intolerance, food sensitivity, or possibly celiac disease.

Headline: Are you getting enough sleep… or too much? Sleep and stroke risk
How safe is exercise during pregnancy?
Summary: While women often have questions about exercise during pregnancy, it is usually not only safe but encouraged because it can help with weight gain, lower risk for certain conditions, and boost mood and psychological well-being.

Headline: Beyond heart health: Could your statin help prevent liver cancer?
Summary: Statins have been prescribed for decades to lower cholesterol, but a recent study found that one type of statin may provide people with certain kinds of liver disease protection from developing liver cancer.

Headline: The new coronavirus: What we do — and don’t — know
Summary: A novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, China, has grown quickly since late December. This primer on what we do –– and don’t  –– know can help if you’re concerned about this rapidly evolving public health issue.

Headline: Think hard before shaming children
Summary: Parents may offer what they think is constructive criticism to a child, but there is a fine line between criticism and shaming, and shaming can have lasting effects on a child’s self-esteem.

Headline: The hype on hyaluronic acid
Summary: A variety of beauty and skincare products now contain hyaluronic acid, a substance naturally found in the body that retains moisture. But what benefits do these products offer, and are they worth using?

Headline: What can you do to reduce the risk of birth defects?
Summary: Women who are hoping to become pregnant want to do everything they can to ensure that their babies will be as healthy as possible, which means following recommendations to minimize the possibility of birth defects.

Headline: Is your cell phone dangerous to your health?
Summary: Plenty of us use our phones in situations when we probably should be paying more attention. But how often does this behavior lead to actual injury? A data analysis offers some answers.

Headline: LDL cholesterol: How low can you (safely) go?
Summary: Lowering LDL cholesterol has been shown to lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Recent studies have suggested that more aggressive goals for LDL levels in people who already have CVD can decrease risk even further.

Headline: Menopause and insomnia: Could a low-GI diet help?
Summary: Researchers examining dietary data from over 50,000 postmenopausal women found that women who ate foods with a higher glycemic index, and foods with more added sugars, were more likely to have insomnia.

Headline: Diabetic retinopathy: Understanding diabetes-related eye disease and vision loss
Summary: Over seven million people have diabetic retinopathy, the most common form of vision loss in working-age adults with diabetes. It’s recommended that people with diabetes should work to keep blood pressure in the normal range and their A1c level below 7% to avoid complications such as diabetic retinopathy.

Headline: Coming clean: Your anesthesiologist needs to know about marijuana use before surgery
Summary: Regular marijuana users who need surgery should disclose their use ahead of the procedure, because of its effects on the body and on the anesthesia medications required for sedation.

Headline: What to do when your child swears
Summary: Even young children can surprise a parent with salty language. Regardless of where they first heard it, use the occasion to help your child learn appropriate behavior in and outside the home.

Headline: Are polypills and population-based treatment the next big things?
Vaccines for women: Before conception, during pregnancy, and after a birth
What are ultra-processed foods and are they bad for our health?
Summary: Health advice tells us to eat less processed food, but what does that mean? Researchers compared diets with most of the calories from unprocessed foods and from ultra-processed foods, to see how the subjects were affected.
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: Harvard Health Ad Watch: When marketing puts your health at risk
What parents need to know about a vegan diet
Vestibular migraine: Progress in the search for treatments
Summary: A sense of dizziness or spinning associated with migraine headache is called vestibular migraine. A small study found that a type of nerve stimulation treatment improved symptoms of vestibular migraine in study participants.

Headline: Why medical research keeps changing its mind
Congenital heart disease and autism: A possible link?
Summary: A recent study confirms that people born with congenital heart disease have a significantly greater risk of being diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder. The research highlights the need for autism screening in children with CHD as early as possible.

Headline: Getting sleep in the hospital
Summary: There are many things about hospital routines that make it difficult for patients to sleep well. If you find yourself hospitalized, there are things you can do to improve the chances that you will get a better night’s sleep.

Headline: An omnivore’s dilemma: How much red meat is too much?
Should you use probiotics for your vagina?
Summary: Probiotics are being promoted as a way for women to improve vaginal health, but unlike with the gut and digestion, there is almost no evidence for any benefit.

Headline: Eosinophilic esophagitis: A new food-related allergic condition on the rise?
Summary: Eosinophilic esophagitis is an allergic inflammation of the esophagus that most typically develops as an allergic response to certain foods. The exact cause is unclear, but if left untreated it can lead to permanent scarring or narrowing of the esophagus.

Headline: How to help your baby through shots and blood tests
A new look at steroid injections for knee and hip osteoarthritis
Researchers urge prostate cancer screening for men with BRCA gene defects
Summary: Prostate cancer screening with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test has been criticized for flagging too many slow-growing tumors that might never be life-threatening. But some men have inherited gene defects that boost their risk of developing prostate cancers that can be quite aggressive. Is PSA screening particularly well-suited for these genetically defined groups? New research […]

Headline: Wearables and sleep: What can they really tell us?
Summary: Many people now wear smartwatches and other wrist-based devices, and use them to collect and track information about their sleep. But the algorithms that govern how the devices work are opaque, and there is no data comparing them to devices that sleep researchers use.

Headline: A low-tech school vacation: Keeping kids busy and happy without screens
Drills, needles, and pain, oh my! Coping with dental anxiety
Summary: Does the mere thought of going to the dentist make you anxious? You aren’t alone, but avoiding dental care appointments can lead to other health problems besides dental pain. But there are steps you can take to relieve that anxiety.

Headline: Infertility: Grandparents in waiting
Summary: Parents of adult children who are struggling with infertility experience complicated feelings, both for what their child is going through and for themselves. Knowing how to deal with these feelings can make the situation easier for everyone involved.

Headline: DOACs now recommended over warfarin to prevent blood clots in people with atrial fibrillation
Summary: For decades, people with atrial fibrillation were prescribed warfarin to prevent blood clots. But a new type of anticoagulant medication (known as DOACs) that came on the market in 2010 has proven to be at least as effective as warfarin, with fewer side effects and without the need for blood test monitoring.

Headline: Weight loss surgery for children and teens struggling with obesity
Lasmiditan: New first-in-class drug treatment approved for migraine
Sexually transmitted infections are on the rise: Should you worry?
Trouble with crossword puzzles? Improve your semantic memory
Summary: Semantic memory is your store of factual knowledge and the meanings of words. It also helps you recall nonverbal concepts and relationships between words and concepts. And while some aspects of memory may decline with age, semantic memory does not.

Headline: Medications as effective as stents for most with coronary artery disease
Summary: A recent study found that for most people with stable coronary artery disease, a conservative treatment strategy was just as effective as a more invasive approach involving cardiac catheterization and stent placement.

Headline: Got children? How to get out the door on time
Summary: Having trouble getting younger kids ready to leave home on time in the morning? Try these strategies to motivate them to accomplish morning-routine tasks.

Headline: Psoriasis and cancer: What’s the link?
Summary: An analysis of studies found an association between people with psoriasis and an increased risk of developing several types of cancer. While this does not establish a definitive link, psoriasis is a relatively common condition and those who have it should be aware of its implications.

Headline: The complicated relationship between fish oil and heart health
Can monitoring blood pressure at home cut maternal mortality?
Summary: Preeclampsia is a dangerous condition marked by hypertension that affects some women during late pregnancy or early weeks after birth. Rising rates of high blood pressure and maternal age increase risk for it. A recent study finds monitoring blood pressure at home may help.

Headline: Most men can hold off on radiation after prostate cancer surgery
Summary: Decisions about follow-up care after prostate cancer surgery sometimes involve a basic choice. If the cancer had features that predict it could return, doctors will likely recommend radiation therapy. But when should a man get that treatment? Should he get the radiation right away, even if there’s no evidence of cancer in the body (this […]

Headline: How to talk to children about the serious illness of a loved one
Could white-coat hypertension harm your heart?
Summary: People who have elevated blood pressure readings in a doctor’s office but normal readings elsewhere are said to have white-coat hypertension. A new study suggests that people with this condition face a greater risk of heart disease than those whose blood pressure is always normal.

Headline: Will a purpose-driven life help you live longer?
A clue to a cure for Alzheimer’s disease
Summary: Half of people who live to 85 will develop Alzheimer’s disease — a disturbing statistic. But research into a family in South America has revealed a gene mutation that appears to afford protection, and may lead to a way to treat or possibly even prevent the disease.

Headline: Living with Crohn’s disease: Recognizing and managing flares
Yes, you can avoid weight gain over the holidays!
Summary: The holiday season presents a challenge to even to those most dedicated to health-conscious eating. Generally, people tend to gain a little weight during the holidays, but a study found that it is possible to avoid extra pounds.

Headline: Darolutamide approved for nonmetastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer
Summary: Sometimes after finishing prostate cancer treatment, men get an unwelcome surprise: their prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels creep higher, suggesting tumors too small to be seen lurk somewhere in the body. This leads to several options. Doctors can continue to monitor a man’s condition with imaging scans. Or, given the anxiety associated with rising PSA, they […]

Headline: Harvard Health Ad Watch: A fibromyalgia treatment ("But you look so good!")
A look at the effects of nail polish on nail health and safety
Summary: Different types of nail polish can have varying effects on fingernails, and have pros and cons depending on the chemicals used in making them.

Headline: Suffering from “chemo brain”? There’s hope and many things you can do
Summary: Over the past decade, research has revealed that the majority of patients treated for cancer experience difficulties with memory, attention, concentration, and thinking. There are several lifestyle actions that can help improve these symptoms, as well as certain medications.

Headline: Benefits of incorporating more aerobic activity into stroke rehabilitation
Summary: Stroke survivors are typically discharged with a program of exercises meant to help them regain independence. But researchers found that an aerobic training in a stroke rehabilitation program similar to that offered to some heart attack patients helped stroke patients improve their aerobic capacity.

Headline: Why are women using CBD products — and do they work?
Summary: Many products containing CBD claim to help women with various health issues, including sleep, mood, symptoms of PMS or menopause, and sexual pleasure. Currently, very little evidence supports these extravagant promises, and there are concerns about the quality and safety of CBD products.

Headline: Think your child has ADHD? What your pediatrician can — and should — do
Summary: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) affects 7% to 8% of children in the US. If you think your child may have ADHD, see your pediatrician, who can take the correct steps toward diagnosis and, if needed, proper treatment and a follow-up plan.

Headline: Chronic fatigue syndrome: Gradually figuring out what’s wrong
Summary: In the 1980s, there was no official definition of what is now known as myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS). But since then, more than 9,000 studies have advanced the understanding of this condition and its effects on people.

Headline: Straight talk on planking
Summary: Your core muscles are your body’s foundation, and the plank pose is a great exercise to do to help build core strength—it’s challenging but not complicated. Here’s everything you need to know to plank correctly.

Headline: Curcumin for arthritis: Does it really work?
What is palliative care, and who can benefit from it?
HPV and cancer: The underappreciated connection
Stopping the vicious cycle of rebound headaches
Summary: People who get frequent headaches and need to take medication at least 15 days a month may be at risk for medication overuse headaches, or “rebound headaches.” Treatment depends on the medication being taken.

Headline: In defense of the salt shaker
Summary: Most people know that too much salt is bad for them and they should try to cut back, but many don’t realize it’s also possible to consume too little salt. It’s not a common problem, but it does happen and it can be harmful.

Headline: How to foster independence in children
Summary: If you’re a parent, part of your role is to prepare your children for adult life by teaching and otherwise encouraging independence. But how does one start to do this?

Headline: Bad flu season predicted — did you get your shot?
Summary: This year’s flu season may be severe. Almost everyone should get vaccinated, but which vaccine might be best for you? And how else can you avoid the flu?

Headline: Lifestyle changes to lower heart disease risk
Vaping: It’s hard to quit, but help is available
Plant-based diets are best… or are they?
Which is better for reading to your toddler: Print or ebooks?
Summary: When reading to a young child, does it matter whether the book is a physical book or in some electronic form? One small study did detect a difference.

Headline: Bisexuality and health: The cost of invisibility
Summary: People who identify as bisexual represent a substantial part of the population, yet research focusing on their health lags. Which health problems are more likely to occur in people who are bisexual and what might help to counter them?

Headline: Hope and caution during infertility treatment
Think your child might have a disability or developmental delay? Take these steps
Summary: If you think your child may have a disability or problem with development, it’s important to seek help as soon as possible. Talk to your doctor, and seek an evaluation, if needed.

Headline: Can exercise help treat anxiety?
Summary: Millions of Americans report having an anxiety disorder. Evidence shows engaging in any sort of physical activity is one of the best ways to ease symptoms of anxiety. Regular activity is best, but even a single bout can help.

Headline: Making young minds resilient to disasters
Summary: Trauma from experiencing a natural disaster can have long-term effects on the mental and physical health of children. Supportive parents, teachers, and other adults can help children build resilience.

Headline: Preventing falls in older adults: Multiple strategies are better
Summary: Falls among older adults are on the rise, but most are preventable. To do this, interventions must target the multiple factors that contribute to falls, taking steps to minimize them or prevent them entirely.

Headline: Is it time to stop skimming over full-fat dairy?
Summary: For years, the conventional wisdom about dairy is that we should be eating less of it, and when we do have any it should be low-fat or fat-free. But more recent research suggests that some full-fat dairy in our diets could in fact be beneficial, though the type of dairy still matters.

Headline: Recurrent headaches in children: What to know and do
Summary: Most children have an occasional headache, but some children get recurrent headaches. These often run in families and may be migraine or tension headaches or might stem from other causes.

Headline: Is there really a blood test to diagnose concussion?
Summary: Can a blood test tell whether or not you have a concussion? It’s not quite that simple. There is a test that indicates the presence of substances released into the blood after a brain injury, but for now it is more useful for identifying situations when a CT scan is not necessary.

Headline: If you are happy and you know it… you may live longer
Summary: Plenty of research associates optimism with a reduced risk of certain diseases and conditions. Now, a study suggests that optimistic people are also more likely to live longer.

Headline: Harvard Health Ad Watch: A new treatment for knee arthritis
Antibiotic-resistant urinary tract infections are on the rise
Summary: Rising resistance to antibiotics driven by overpresciption and overuse has led to a decline in the effectiveness of antibiotics in treating urinary tract infections. If your doctor wants to prescribe an antibiotic, be sure to ask if it’s necessary, and what alternatives there might be.

Headline: Too old for the pediatrician? Time to switch doctors
Summary: Wondering how a teen or young adult can smoothly smoothly transition from seeing a pediatrician to a medical practice that treats adults? Making plans and taking these steps will help.

Headline: Should I participate in a cardiac rehabilitation program?
Summary: For people who have had a heart attack or heart surgery, or been diagnosed with angina or a specific kind of heart failure, participating in a cardiac rehabilitation program has medically proven benefits to overall health and quality of life.

Headline: Gene testing to guide antidepressant treatment: Has its time arrived?
Can your CPAP make you sick?
Summary: Using a CPAP machine is beneficial for people with obstructive sleep apnea, but if the machine isn’t kept clean it could lead to an illness. There are sanitizing systems available, but cleaning the parts by hand is just as effective.

Headline: 10 foods that may impact your risk of dying from heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes
Summary: Researchers examining data from a national health survey and other sources found that consuming too much, or too little, of 10 foods was associated with 45% of deaths in 2012 due to type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and stroke.

Headline: PrEP prevents HIV — so why aren’t more people taking it?
Summary: PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis) is a daily medication taken to prevent HIV infection. While multiple studies show PrEP is effective, relatively few of those who might benefit are taking it. Will a 10-year initiative to reduce rates of HIV and a new formulation of PrEP help?

Headline: Chronic Lyme arthritis: A mystery solved?
Study supports benefit of statin use for older adults
Summary: Statins are known to be effective in reducing risk of cardiovascular disease, but for older adults the guidelines are less clear. A study looking at an older population found that continuing to take statins did have a statistically significant benefit.

Headline: Dense breasts on a mammogram? What to know and do
Summary: Mammograms look for signs of breast cancer. They can also provide information on whether a woman has high breast density, which slightly increases risk for developing breast cancer. Here’s what you need to know and do if you’re notified about this risk factor.

Headline: If you have migraines, put down your coffee and read this
Popular heartburn drug ranitidine recalled: What you need to know and do
Is there a test for Alzheimer’s disease?
Summary: Wondering whether a blood test or brain scan can accurately diagnose Alzheimer’s disease? If memory loss is a problem for you or a loved one, consider these points before discussing potential next steps with a doctor.

Headline: Vitiligo: More than skin deep
Summary: Approximately 1% of the population has vitiligo, a skin condition in which areas of skin lose their color. While topical treatments and light therapy help some, research with a class of medications not previously used for this condition has shown promising results.

Headline: What donor offspring seek when they do DNA testing
Summary: Readily available DNA testing unexpectedly changed some family trees. But people who grew up knowing –– or recently learned –– they were donor-conceived may have differing reasons for wanting to better understand their personal stories.

Headline: Weekend catch-up sleep won’t fix the effects of sleep deprivation on your waistline
Summary: Trying to make up for not getting enough sleep during the week by sleeping longer on weekends has been found to have negative effects such as weight gain, expending less energy, and increased calorie intake during evenings.

Headline: Intensive blood sugar control doesn’t have lasting cardiovascular benefits for those with diabetes
Summary: A recent 15-year follow-up to the Veterans Affairs Diabetes Trial found that short-term intensive blood sugar control did not lead to significant reduction of risk of cardiovascular events in the long term.

Headline: Adult acne: Understanding underlying causes and banishing breakouts
Common hormonal treatments linked to abnormal heart rhythms and sudden death in men being treated for prostate cancer
Summary: Treatments for advanced prostate cancer that suppress testosterone, a hormone (also called an androgen) that drives the malignant cells to grow and spread, are collectively referred to as androgen deprivation therapies, or ADT. These therapies can significantly extend lifespans in men who have the disease, but they also have a range of challenging side effects. […]

Headline: Harvard Health Ad Watch: How direct-to-consumer ads hook us
Summary: Direct-to-consumer (DTC) drug ads promoting treatments for arthritis, cancer, heartburn, psoriasis, flagging memory, and more are all everywhere you look. All too often, the information shared is incomplete, biased, or confusing––here's what to watch out for and how to get the whole story when considering treatment options.

Headline: New medication advances treatment for chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps
Summary: The FDA has approved a new medication for the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, dupilumab, which is given by injection biweekly.

Headline: Does Botox reduce the frequency of chronic migraine?
Summary: People who experience chronic migraine headaches may benefit from treatment with botulimun neurotoxin (Botox), though other treatments such as medication are usually tried first.

Headline: Want to travel back in time? Use episodic memory
Sleep driving and other unusual practices during sleep
Summary: The FDA has issued its most serious category of warning about three sleep medications due to reports of injuries related to their use. Aside from next-day drowsiness, these medications can cause sleep behaviors that may be dangerous.

Headline: How racism harms children
Your risk of dementia: Do lifestyle and genetics matter?
Summary: Clinical trials for drugs to stop or slow the progression of dementia have not been successful. A recent study attempted to determine how much influence, if any, genetic and lifestyle factors may have on the development of dementia.

Headline: Psychotherapy leads in treating post-traumatic stress disorder
Summary: Expert recommendations for treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) differ. New research supports trying certain types of psychotherapy first, followed by medication if needed, or starting off with a combination of both.

Headline: Why are diabetes-related complications on the rise?
Summary: From 1990 to 2010, there was a significant decrease in diabetes-related complications, but since then the trend has reversed and complications are on the rise among young adults. This may be due to the changing profile of those who develop type 2 diabetes, or may be due to other factors.

Headline: Save the trees, prevent the sneeze
Summary: If it seems like your seasonal allergies are worse than they used to be, you aren’t imagining it, and you aren’t alone. Climate change has caused a longer pollen season, and plants are producing more pollen that is more potent.

Headline: Feeling gassy — is it ever a cause for concern?
Summary: Intestinal gas can be embarrassing, but is a normal part of digestion. Only rarely is excess gas cause for concern. Which foods you eat –– and how you digest them –– can make a difference.

Headline: Bad viruses travel fast: Measles vaccine important for travelers
Summary: Because measles is so highly contagious, and because there is a significant delay before symptoms manifest, a person can carry the virus and infect others without knowing it, and many adults may not have received an effective dose of the vaccine. Many outbreaks of measles could probably be prevented if more travelers received MMR vaccine prior to foreign travel.

Headline: Leg pain when you walk? Don’t ignore it
Summary: Leg pain when walking that eases with rest may be a sign of peripheral artery disease, which raises risk for other cardiovascular problems. Lifestyle changes — keep walking! — and treatment help.

Headline: A new drug for low sexual desire in women: Bremelanotide
Summary: The FDA approved a new medication that may help some women experiencing low sexual desire, but there are restrictions on who can take it, and side effects to consider.

Headline: Can vaping damage your lungs? What we do (and don’t) know
New donor screening protocols for clinical trials involving fecal microbiota transplantation
Avoiding nuts and seeds for better gut health? You shouldn’t
Summary: Nuts and seeds are rich in fiber, which is important for gut health and keeping you regular. And, contrary to a common concern, no evidence links eating nuts and seeds to a painful gut infection called diverticulitis.

Headline: Driving for teens with ADHD: What parents need to know
Summary: Parents always worry when a teen starts driving –– even more so if a teen has ADHD. Research shows teens with ADHD have a higher risk for auto accidents. Here’s how to reduce that risk.

Headline: Simple ways to wake up your workout
Summary: Avoid boredom and boost the benefits you gain from exercise with these simple tips to wake up your weight or treadmill workout.

Headline: Stress-eating: Five strategies to slow down
How early can you — and should you — diagnose autism?
Summary: If a parent thinks a child might have autism, it helps to get a definitive diagnosis as early as possible, since the earlier treatment can begin, the better it is for the child. But at what age can a reliable diagnosis be made?

Headline: When it comes to cholesterol levels, white meat may be no better than red meat — and plant-based protein beats both
Summary: Plenty of people avoid red meat or eat only small amounts of it. But relying on white meat for protein may not be such a good nutrition choice either. According to the results of a small study, those who ate red meat and white meat had similarly higher cholesterol levels.

Headline: Talking to your doctor about your LGBTQ+ sex life
Summary: Talking about sexuality with a doctor can be uncomfortable. If you identify as LGBTQ+, it’s important to find a doctor who is attuned to the specific needs of the LGBTQ+ community. This can make getting proper care easier.

Headline: Why do you need a primary care physician?
Summary: Primary care physicians treat adult patients for common ailments and chronic conditions, and also manage their patients’ treatments, often working with teams of caregivers. Establishing a relationship with a PCP allows your doctor to get to know you and your needs and goals.

Headline: Teens and confidentiality
Summary: Offering teens privacy and confidentiality when meeting with a health care provider may allow them to discuss uncomfortable topics –– such as risky behavior, physical concerns, feeling anxious or depressed –– a step toward getting needed information and help.

Headline: Impossible and Beyond: How healthy are these meatless burgers?
I’m in pain, so why is my doctor suggesting a psychologist?
Summary: The negative emotions that come from coping with chronic pain can lead to depression, and that very depression can lead to worse pain. Understanding the connection between pain and emotional health with the help of a psychologist can address these issues, and there are evidence-based therapies that can help as well.

Headline: Do employee wellness programs actually work?
Popular drugs used for treating enlarged prostates associated with high-grade prostate cancer
Summary: If a man has an enlarged prostate, there’s a good chance he’ll be treated with a type of drug called a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor (5-ARI). These drugs shrink the gland to improve urinary flow, and the approved forms used for treating enlarged prostates come in two varieties: Proscar (finasteride) and Avodart (dutasteride). However, a side […]

Headline: Is there a role for surgery in treating Hashimoto’s thyroiditis?
Summary: A small European study compared standard treatment for the autoimmune condition Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (thyroid medication) with surgery to remove the thyroid. Those who had surgery saw significant improvement.

Headline: Keeping children safe around cosmetics
Summary: Between 2002 and 2016, over 4,000 children under 5 were treated each year in US emergency departments for cosmetics-related injuries. Take precautions with your cosmetic products to keep children safe.

Headline: Want a sharp mind, strong memory? Ramp up activities
Summary: Research shows that older people who are socially engaged and keep their minds active are more likely to remain mentally sharp. But what specific activities should people do? And does it matter if they start late in life or sooner?

Headline: Kratom: Fear-worthy foliage or beneficial botanical?
Are antibacterial products with triclosan fueling bacterial resistance?
What should you do if your blood pressure medication has been recalled?
Summary: The FDA has recalled certain kinds of blood pressure medications due to the presence of impurities that occur during the manufacturing process. The added risk from the presence of these substances is low, but it’s important to know which medications are affected, and what you should do if you are taking one of them.

Headline: Why do parents worry about vaccines?
Summary: The ongoing measles epidemic spotlights the importance of vaccinations –– and the concerns some parents have about vaccine safety. If you have such concerns, talk to your child’s doctor and learn more about vaccine safety.

Headline: Brain-based devices: How well do they work?
Summary: Brain-based devices claim to offer all kinds of enhancements and improvements, but how can consumers interested in such a device separate legitimate science from mere hype?

Headline: Keep using sunscreen while FDA updates recommendations on safety of sunscreen ingredients
Should you see a chiropractor for low back pain?
New FDA-approved weight loss device shows promise
Summary: Not everyone who needs to lose weight is a good candidate for either surgery or medications, so more treatment options are valuable. The FDA has approved a new device to help people lose weight, a capsule containing particles that expand in the stomach.

Headline: From Brexit to TRexit: Transperineal biopsies pose a challenge to the traditional transrectal biopsy method
Summary: By now most of us are familiar with Brexit, the UK’s pending divorce with the European Union. But in a play on that term, British doctors are also moving towards an exit they’ve dubbed “TRexit” from the most common sort of prostate biopsy: the transrectal ultrasound guided biopsy, or TRUS. Men who test positive on […]

Headline: HPV vaccine: A vaccine that works, and one all children should get
Summary: Human papilloma virus (HPV) causes about 40,000 cases of cancer every year. A long-term study of the HPV vaccine finds it offers protection against many strains of the virus, yet many teens haven’t had this safe, effective vaccine.

Headline: The DASH diet: A great way to eat foods that are healthy AND delicious
Summary: The DASH diet has already been shown to lower blood pressure, and a new study found that people who followed it closely had a lower risk of heart failure. Try these suggestions to incorporate the DASH diet into your daily eating pattern.

Headline: Opioids for acute pain: How much is too much?
Summary: One of the roots of the opioid crisis in the US is how frequently the medications are prescribed. There are times when a prescription opioid is called for, but in many cases an over-the-counter pain medication is very effective.
Category: Scott Weiner, MD, MPH, FACEP, FAAEM

Headline: DNA testing forever changed donor conception
Summary: DNA testing kits can upend identity and spark a multitude of questions for some children conceived with donor sperm and parents who hadn’t shared origin stories.

Headline: Is my thyroid making enough hormone?
Children and gun safety: What to know and do
Summary: Regardless of individual feelings about guns and gun ownership, everyone wants their children to be safe. Simple safety steps can prevent accidents involving children and guns.

Headline: Kidney stones: What are your treatment options?
Summary: There are several treatment options for kidney stones. Which is best for you may depend on size and number of stones and their location in the kidney. Imaging and blood tests can help your doctor determine the right course of treatment.

Headline: A new therapy for osteoporosis: Romosozumab
Summary: Osteoporosis affects 10 million people in the United States, the majority of them women. Romosozumab is a new type of medication for treating osteoporosis that offers another treatment option for some women after menopause.

Headline: The fourth trimester: What you should know
Dermal fillers: The good, the bad and the dangerous
Infant car seats are for cars only (how not to use an infant car seat)
Summary: If you use an infant car seat that detaches from the base, it may be convenient to leave your baby in it even when not in a car, but the American Academy of Pediatrics warns people that these seats should be used only for travel in a vehicle.

Headline: 10,000 steps a day — or fewer?
Summary: If you’re trying to take 10,000 steps a day, it can be discouraging to miss that well-known target. But why is 10,000 steps the goal? And is it really necessary to take that many steps every day?

Headline: 4 behavioral changes to tame urinary incontinence
Summary: The discomfort and potential embarrassment of urinary incontinence keeps many people from the activities they enjoy, but some simple behavioral changes can improve bladder control.

Headline: Hyperemesis: (Way) beyond morning sickness
More opioids, more pain: Fueling the fire
Summary: One of the paradoxes of treating pain is that the longer a person takes an opioid medication, the greater possibility they will become more sensitive to pain, a condition called opioid-induced hyperalgesia.

Headline: Supporting your newborn’s health: Intestinal colonization after elective cesarean section
Digesting the latest research on eggs
Summary: Another study is questioning the healthfulness of eggs, but whether or not you should eat fewer eggs depends on your overall diet and your risk of cardiovascular disease.

Headline: Hands-only CPR: A lifesaving technique within your reach
Summary: For more than a decade, national guidelines have recommended the simpler, hands-only version of CPR for cardiac arrests that occur outside a hospital. Even if you haven’t had a training course, administering CPR keeps blood circulating in a cardiac arrest victim until medical help arrives.

Headline: Simplify your workout with lap swimming
Summary: Lap swimming is a very effective workout: aerobics, strengthening, and stretching in one activity. Make sure you’re reasonably healthy before diving in, but even if you’re not, or if you don’t know how to swim, aquatic exercises are beneficial, too.

Headline: Colorectal cancer screening before age 50?
Trouble reading? Try these workarounds
Showering daily -- is it necessary?
Thunderclap headache: The “worst headache of my life”
Summary: A thunderclap headache is a sudden, extremely severe headache associated with several possible causes. It’s considered a medical emergency and should be treated as soon as possible.

Headline: Fiber-full eating for better health and lower cholesterol
Trouble keeping information in mind? Could be sleep, mood — or age
Summary: Most people experience some degree of decreased memory as they get older, but memory performance is also affected by mood and sleep quality, and these are factors that can be controlled and improved.

Headline: Can a man with abnormal PSA and a negative diagnostic MRI avoid a prostate biopsy? It’s debatable
Summary: Not long ago, an abnormal PSA reading would be followed right away by a standard biopsy to search for potential cancer in the prostate. During such a procedure, doctors take 10 to 12 samples of the prostate from various locations while looking at the gland with an ultrasound machine. These days, however, men with high […]

Headline: Healthy eating for older adults
Summary: As people get older, changes in metabolism and appetite can make it more difficult to get the right amount and kind of nutrition. But it’s still possible to eat healthily regardless of your age.
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: Is an opioid really the best medication for my pain?
Summary: With all the concern around opioid medications and the risk of addiction, it’s understandable that a person might be hesitant if prescribed an opioid. Many factors need to be weighed in making this decision, including the type of pain, the cause, and how long it has persisted.

Headline: A poor sense of smell might matter more than you thought
The 6 don’ts of caring for your child’s teeth
Summary: Tooth decay is linked to a higher risk of many health problems in adulthood, but often families don’t put enough emphasis on proper and consistent dental care. Avoiding these mistakes can help your children get the right start on their oral health.

Headline: Is tramadol a risky pain medication?
Summary: Tramadol is a unique prescription pain medicine similar to opioids. Research finds people taking it had a higher risk of dying than those taking other pain medicines. But a confounding factor may make tramadol seem more risky than it really is.

Headline: Father’s Day: Tools for coping when celebration brings pain
Summary: While Father’s Day gets less sentimental build up than Mother’s Day, it may still bring out intense emotions for many men even if they are not parents themselves.

Headline: Brain health rests on heart health: Guidelines for lifestyle changes
Summary: The World Health Organization has issued prevention guidelines for preventing dementia. Of note, the guidelines are very similar to those for heart health, reinforcing the known connections between heart health and brain health.

Headline: Headaches: What to know, when to worry
When making summer plans for children, leave some time unplanned
Summary: Parents want their kids to have fun on summer vacation, but also for their time to be productive in some way. The best way to facilitate this is to allow for unscheduled time to foster self-directed creative thinking.

Headline: Can an eye exam reveal Alzheimer’s risk?
Summary: New research considers whether certain eye conditions may help predict Alzheimer’s disease. The common link? Cardiovascular disease, which is partly preventable.

Headline: Healthy meals: 3 easy steps to success
Cannabis is medicine — don’t make it taste good
Summary: The increasing availability of cannabis-containing edibles has fueled debate about their safety. As emergency visits rise for treatment related to edibles, some common-sense thinking about how these products are packaged and sold is needed.

Headline: I see you, but don't ask me how I'm doing
Human insulin may be a lower-cost option for some people with diabetes
FDA curbs unfounded memory supplement claims
Topical treatment helps prevent actinic keratosis from developing into skin cancer
Summary: Actinic keratoses are scaly areas on the skin that, if left untreated, may develop into squamous cell skin cancers. A recent study compared several topical treatments used by dermatologists to treat this condition.

Headline: Are certain types of sugars healthier than others?
Anxiety in college: What we know and how to cope
Beer before wine? Wine before beer?
Summary: Ever wonder whether order matters if you switch between drinking wine and beer? Well, researchers asked this question. The answer may surprise you (or not).

Headline: Measles: The forgotten killer
Ketamine for major depression: New tool, new questions
Public policies to stop kids from drinking sugary drinks
Summary: Concern about the amount of sugar in kids’ diets has led the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Heart Association to encourage the consideration of steps to reduce the consumption of sugary drinks among children and teens.

Headline: Herpes infection of the cornea
What causes kidney stones (and what to do)
Summary: You’re more likely to get kidney stones, or have them recur, if you don’t drink enough fluid each day. Proper hydration, medication, and attention to diet are the most common treatments.

Headline: Treating constipation with biofeedback for the pelvic floor
Summary: People with constipation caused by pelvic floor dysfunction may benefit from a course of physical therapy that uses biofeedback to detect the movements of various muscles, and provides guidance on how to retrain the pelvic floor muscles.

Headline: Microbiome: The first 1,000 days
Summary: From the time of conception until the second year of life, appropriate bacteria colonization of the digestive tract affects long-term health and plays a role in whether a person will be healthy or will develop a chronic disease.

Headline: Young children are swallowing objects twice as often as before
Summary: Researchers found that the incidence of children swallowing nonfood items had increased dramatically between the mid-1990s and the mid-2010s. Practicing good safety habits and taking certain other precautions is the best way to prevent such incidents.

Headline: Big problems for big toe joints
Summary: Shoes with a tight toe box or too-high heels can contribute to big toe joint problems like bunions and osteoarthritis. Surgery may be needed, or simple steps could help ease pain and keep you moving.

Category: Scott Weiner, MD, MPH, FACEP, FAAEM

Headline: Stool transplants are now standard of care for recurrent C. difficile infections
The latest deadly superbug, and why it's not time to panic
5 ways we can help our children succeed
Summary: The recent college admission scandal has raised the issue of parents helping their children succeed. Regardless of where (or whether) someone goes to college, parents and other caregivers can help children learn the traits and skills that will help them learn how to find their way in the world.

Headline: Intensive treatment of blood pressure helps prevent memory decline in older adults
Summary: The results of a study on cardiovascular health and memory found that people who received intensive treatment to lower their blood pressure were significantly less likely to develop mild cognitive impairment.

Headline: Going public with sobriety
Summary: Substance use disorders like alcoholism and drug addiction are stigmatized in our society, so why would someone—not just anyone, but a doctor— go public with his struggle?

Headline: The trouble with new drugs
Summary: Although drugs have to pass clinical trials before being approved, sometimes side effects do not become apparent until a wider population has used them. The FDA monitors medications after they are available to the public, and issues alerts and warnings when appropriate.

Headline: Baby boomers and hepatitis C: What’s the connection?
Summary: Because those in the baby boom generation account for around 75% of hepatitis C cases, the CDC and USPSTF are recommending that all baby boomers should get screened for the hepatitis C virus.

Headline: Moving from couch to 5K
Highly accurate test reveals recurring prostate cancer
Summary: After being treated for prostate cancer, some men will experience a rise in PSA levels suggesting that new tumors lurk somewhere in the body. Finding these tiny cancerous deposits before they grow and spread any further is crucially important. But it’s also a challenge, since the budding tumors might be too small to see with […]

Headline: TAVR: Aortic valve replacement without open-heart surgery
Summary: A catheter-based treatment for aortic stenosis has shown good results in higher-risk patients, and recent clinical trials in lower-risk candidates have also been favorable, meaning that this treatment will likely become the standard for all patients with this condition.

Headline: Mother’s Day: Tools for coping when celebration brings pain
Summary: Mother’s Day is meant to be a day of celebration. But for many women it can also be a day of discomfort. Tools for coping may make this easier to manage.

Headline: Ease anxiety and stress: Take a (belly) breather
Phytonutrients: Paint your plate with the colors of the rainbow
Summary: Phytonutrients in fruits and vegetables can protect us from chronic diseases if we eat enough of them. Because different produce contains different phytonutrients, consuming as much of a variety as possible is the best way to benefit from this protection.
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: MitraClip: Valve repair device offers new treatment option for some with severe mitral regurgitation
Summary: Mitral valve regurgitation is a condition in which the heart’s mitral valve does not close properly. Until recently this could only be treated by medication or surgery, but a new device helps “close the gap” between the faulty valves.

Headline: Activity: It all counts
Summary: When it comes to physical activity and fitness, most of us could do more than we are doing, but the good news is that as long as you’re doing something, any amount of activity is beneficial, and more exercise is definitely associated with a lower risk of death.

Headline: Infertility: Extra embryos –– too much of a good thing?
Summary: People attempting to conceive through in vitro fertilization may face the question of what to do with extra embryos, especially if they reach a point where they feel their family is complete.

Headline: Eating breakfast won’t help you lose weight, but skipping it might not either
Summary: Eat breakfast? Skip breakfast? Newer research fails to link eating breakfast with eating less or weight loss. So, will skipping breakfast shave off weight?

Headline: The heart and science of kindness
Summary: Acts of kindness — to loved ones, to strangers, to ourselves — make the world a warmer place. And seeking ways to be kind can make you happier, too.

Headline: How to handle stress at work
Summary: Stress at work is common and can lead to burnout, which is linked with depression and anxiety. Strategies from cognitive behavioral therapy can help people learn to manage stress.

Headline: What to do with that foam roller at the gym?
Summary: While there is limited research on foam rollers,  small studies suggest they may help with muscle and tissue tightness, sore muscles, and range of motion.

Headline: 5 reasons we need to help kids live “heads up” instead of “heads down”
Summary: The presence and influence of smartphones in our lives has benefits, but it also creates hazards. For children and teens, too much attention to phones is not just a safety risk, but also deprives them of opportunity to gain life experience and understanding of the world.

Headline: Is obesity a reason to avoid joint replacement surgery?
Brain-gut connection explains why integrative treatments can help relieve digestive ailments
Summary: Because of the strong connection between the brain and the digestive system, stress can cause or worsen many gastrointestinal conditions, and gut inflammation can have effects in other areas of the body. Mind-body treatments can improve digestive symptoms and decrease the stress response.

Headline: Can you strong-arm diabetes?
Easy daily ways to feel more connected

Lead exposure and heart disease
Summary: The harm that lead can cause young children has been known for decades, but there is growing evidence that lead in the blood may raise the risk of heart disease in adults.

Headline: Discontinuation syndrome and antidepressants
Addressing weight bias in medicine
Summary: While there is growing awareness of the complex nature of obesity, many people still experience implicit or overt bias from their doctors and other health care providers. Understanding how this affects the health of people with obesity is a step toward eliminating it.

Summary: One challenge for people with fertility issues is navigating other people’s pregnancies. Support and coping strategies can help maintain relationships.

Summary: Many women feel uncomfortable talking about health issues or concerns relating to the vulva or vagina. This brief primer on vulvar health can help.

Headline: Why the wheelchair? Could it be gout?
Summary: Though only a small percentage of the population has gout, that number is on the rise. While dietary choices have long been believed to be a major cause of gout, a new study found that genetic factors matter much more.

Headline: Safer surgery: Steps you can take
Summary: Millions of Americans have elective surgeries like knee or hip replacements. When choosing a surgeon or procedure, follow these steps to make surgery safer.

Headline: A silver lining for migraine sufferers?

Summary: Racial differences have long been evident in prostate cancer statistics. But new research also shows that African American men who receive the most advanced treatments for late-stage prostate […]

Headline: Preventing depression in pregnancy: New guidelines
Summary: First-ever recommendations from US Preventive Services Task Force aim to help women who experience depression during pregnancy or after childbirth.

Headline: Cleaner living: Plant-friendly is planet-friendly

Summary: Making small, gradual changes to your eating habits and patterns is an easy way to incorporate the Mediterranean diet approach into your life.

Headline: Over-the-counter cold and flu medicines can affect your heart
Summary: Some common over-the-counter medications typically taken for colds and the flu may increase the risk of a cardiovascular event. This increased risk is more likely to occur in people with existing heart disease, and in people who take the medications for an extended period of time.

Headline: How to prevent poisonings in children — and what to do if they happen
Summary: Safety precautions can prevent a child from accidentally ingesting or being exposed to poisonous or harmful items in your home, but knowing what to do if something happens can save a life.

Headline: How long does a joint replacement last?
Summary: A person considering a knee or hip replacement needs to weigh how long the new joint will last as part of the decision-making process. Analyses of hundreds of thousands of hip and knee replacements show encouraging results for those facing this decision.

Headline: Something else to avoid in pregnancy: Phthalates
Banishing dry winter skin
Summary: Using a moisturizer is good for your skin year-round, but a dermatologist explains that during the cold and dry months there’s more you can do to prevent or relieve dry skin.

Headline: Can exercise extend your life?
Summary: Better health and more time: a long-term study of people who took a treadmill test suggests better fitness lengthens lives at every age.

Summary: Sleep is a necessity for everyone, but it’s especially important for older people to be aware of the changes in sleep patterns that accompany aging, and the effect that poor sleep can have on brain health.

Headline: Stretching: Less pain, other gains
Summary: Stay flexible by adding simple stretches to your day and fitness routine. Stretching aids balance and posture, and helps prevent pain and injury.

Headline: Fear of cancer recurrence: Mind-body tools offer hope
Summary: As the number of cancer survivors continues to grow, many continue to worry for years after treatment ends about a recurrence of the disease. These people need post-treatment support, and mind-body techniques offer a promising solution.

Headline: Thinking about rhinoplasty?
Summary: Rhinoplasty is the most common facial plastic surgery procedure. While often done to improve trouble breathing, many people choose to have this surgery for cosmetic reasons. Some have both goals met in one surgery.

Summary: When it’s time for a treat, ice cream is one of the most popular choices. There are now many more “frozen dessert” options besides frozen yogurt, like non-dairy products. Are any of them better for you than ice cream, or worse?

Do you really have a penicillin allergy?
Summary: Many people who believe they are allergic to penicillin do not in fact have this allergy. Additionally, people who were allergic in the past may no longer be. An allergist can use various tests to determine whether a person has a true allergy.

Summary: Men with advanced prostate cancer are typically treated with drugs that prevent the body from making or using testosterone. About 600,000 men with advanced prostate cancer in […]

Headline: Infertility: Maintaining privacy, avoiding secrecy
Summary: Couples coping with infertility also have to decide what to tell family and friends about their situation. It’s possible to preserve privacy by offering a simple truth without unnecessary detail.

Headline: Sweeteners: Time to rethink your choices?
Summary: Non-sugar sweeteners are popular, but there have been questions about their safety, so are they worth it? Researchers examined dozens of studies to assess the risks and benefits of various sweeteners available.

Headline: Should I be eating more fiber?
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: Can facial exercises reverse signs of aging?
Summary: A study found that a regimen of daily facial exercises led to fuller cheeks and a more youthful appearance among participants. But its small size makes it difficult to draw conclusions about the longevity of the results.

Headline: Should you try kettlebells?
Summary: Looking for a way to add variety to your workouts? Consider kettlebells. Kettlebell exercises work several muscle groups at a time, and can help improve posture and balance as well.

Headline: The rise of push-ups: A classic exercise that can help you get stronger
Summary: Basic push-ups engage your body from top to bottom. They work several muscle groups at once including the arms, chest, abdomen (core), hips, and legs. How many you can do at one time offers a simple way to evaluate your strength and muscular endurance and is an easy tool to help you improve. To find your starting point, perform as many push-ups as you can with good form.

Headline: Got pain? Get better sleep
What’s in your supplements?
Summary: Millions of Americans take some kind of supplement, but because supplements are not regulated like prescription drugs are, taking one is not always safe. Researchers have found many instances of hidden ingredients and inaccurate quantities listed on the label.

Headline: A positive mindset can help your heart
Parents don’t always realize that their teen is suicidal
Summary: The life of a teenager can be filled with drama, real or imagined. But while parents may think their teen overreacts too much, parents themselves might under-react to indications that a teen could be contemplating suicide.

Headline: Planet-friendly, plant-based home cooking
Summary: The nutrition building blocks of plant-based meals are vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. These are easy to cook and relatively inexpensive, and people who prepare more meals at home tend to have better health profiles.

Headline: Integrative approaches to reduce IBS symptoms
Summary: Some people with irritable bowel syndrome get relief from medications, but for others they are not a viable or effective option. But there are nondrug treatment options that reduce symptoms for many, including stress reduction techniques, special diets, and certain supplements.

Headline: Tackling parent-teacher conferences: The early years
Summary: Getting ready for a parent-teacher conference? Keep in mind time constraints and prepare by thinking about the questions you most want answered.

Headline: Managing pain after surgery
Summary: Even with all the attention given to the opioid epidemic, it may still be a surprise to some people that prescription pain medication is not always necessary after a surgical procedure. Talking with your doctor about post-surgical pain management will help you understand what to expect.

Headline: In defense of French fries
Summary: Researchers found that frequent consumers of French fries don’t live as long as those who eat them less often, but as is often the case, the conclusion only tells part of the story. Are French fries really a “death food”? Not necessarily, and probably not.

Headline: 4 things everyone needs to know about measles
Summary: The number of measles cases in the US in 2018 more than tripled over those in 2017, and early numbers for this year suggest a continued surge. It’s important for everyone, but especially parents, to know about the virus, its potential complications, and the facts about the vaccine.

Headline: Preserving fertility during cancer treatments
Summary: Cancer treatments –– and some cancers –– can affect fertility in both women and men. Variables include age at diagnosis, type of cancer, and type of treatment. If you’re wondering about options for preserving fertility, discuss this with your treatment team.

Headline: Alternative therapies for cancer
Summary: A study of two million people receiving cancer treatment found that those who chose a complementary treatment along with conventional treatment had less successful outcomes (did not live as long).

Headline: Why keep a food diary?
Summary: For those looking to improve their diet or lose weight, keeping a food diary is a useful tool. Recording information for at least a week will help people identify habits and patterns that will help them set realistic goals.
Category: Katherine D. McManus, MS, RD, LDN

Headline: What to do if you think your child has the flu
Summary: We are in the midst of an active flu season, so if you think your child may have the flu, following this advice will help you and your family get through it a little more easily.

Headline: When a pelvic exam is traumatic
Summary: Women who have experienced sexual violence or trauma are more likely to have anxiety about medical visits, particularly seeing a gynecologist and receiving a pelvic exam. Open communication in both directions is crucial for women to feel safe during these visits.

Headline: Hormonal therapy for aggressive prostate cancer: How long is enough?
Summary: Men weighing treatment options for intermediate- or high-risk cancer that is still localized to the prostate can face a tricky question. A standard approach in these cases is to give radiation to the prostate along with drugs that block testosterone, a hormone that makes the cancer cells grow faster. For how long should this hormone […]

Headline: Your genes and addiction
Summary: As researchers seek new ways to treat addiction as well as ways to prevent it, they are also trying to determine why some people are more susceptible to addiction than others. One such avenue of research involves the interactions of genetic and environmental factors in the brain’s reward system.

Headline: Dairy: Health food or health risk?
Summary: Are dairy products good for us, or not? There’s a lot of conflicting information. Dairy products are good sources of calcium, protein, and vitamin D, but choosing lower-fat versions is still probably better for overall health.

Headline: Couch potatoes start early: How to get kids moving
Summary: A European study found that children became less active starting as early as 6, and activity declined sharply after age 8. More scheduled lives and more time spent using phones and devices are key reasons for this decline, but there are ways parents can encourage activity.

Headline: Post-hospital syndrome: Tips to keep yourself or a loved one healthy after hospitalization
Summary: Post-hospital syndrome is a period of vulnerability after a patient is discharged from the hospital that leaves a person at increased risk for rehospitalization. Patients and their loved ones can take steps to minimize or prevent effects of post-hospital syndrome.

Headline: Immunotherapy: What you need to know
Bad breath: What causes it and what to do about it
Bleeding after menopause: Get it checked out
Summary: Bleeding after menopause is likely caused by a noncancerous condition, but it should always be checked to rule out endometrial cancer, the most common gynecological cancer. It’s very curable if found early, and testing (ultrasound or biopsy) can identify most cases.

Headline: Does weather affect arthritis pain?
Summary: The question of whether there is a link between weather and aches and pains has been studied extensively, and so far researchers have been unable to establish a connection. So why do plenty of people insist that they can “feel” the weather?

Headline: Going Mediterranean to prevent heart disease
Infertility and regret: If only...
Is there a place for coconut oil in a healthy diet?
Summary: With contradictory information circulating about the alleged benefits or hazards of coconut oil, it’s helpful to know more about what it is, why its use has been encouraged, and the arguments against its use.

Headline: Younger kindergarteners more likely to be diagnosed with ADHD
Can watching sports be bad for your health?
Summary: It probably doesn’t seem like watching a sporting event would be a health hazard, and for most people that’s true. However, just watching a game at home on TV can cause a person’s heart rate and blood pressure to rise, which could be dangerous for someone with cardiovascular disease.

Headline: Fatty liver disease: What it is and what to do about it
Surgery for appendicitis? Antibiotics alone may be enough
Summary: While appendectomy is a very common surgery, there is evidence that treating appendicitis with antibiotics instead of surgery is an effective alternative.

Headline: Heart disease and breast cancer: Can women cut risk for both?
Summary: While they share many risk factors, far more women are living with heart disease than with breast cancer. Exercise and a healthy diet can cut a woman’s risk for both.

Headline: Long-term statin use protects against prostate cancer death
Summary: Statins and other drugs that lessen cardiovascular disease risk by lowering blood lipids rank among the world’s most prescribed medications. And for the men who take them, accumulating evidence has for years pointed to another added benefit: a lower risk of developing prostate cancer. Now researchers are reporting that long-term statin use (more than 10 […]

Headline: NSAIDs: How dangerous are they for your heart?
Summary: There is growing evidence that NSAID medications may increase the risk of a heart attack or stroke. The overall risk is quite small, but it can vary depending on the duration of treatment and whether a person has existing cardiovascular disease.

Headline: Working with a disability
Summary: While illnesses and medical conditions may prevent some people from working, millions of Americans are with chronic health conditions are able to work because of legal protections guaranteed under the Americans with Disabilities Act. There are resources available to people who need assistance with work accommodations.

Headline: Grieving? Don’t overlook potential side effects
Summary: The emotional weight of grief affects the body in the form of stress, which can make existing conditions worse or cause new ones, and can also lead to depression. Maintaining health may seem difficult while grieving, but doing so can help rebuild mental strength.

Headline: Acne: What you need to know
Baloxavir (Xofluza): A new antiviral drug for the flu
Summary: A new medication has been approved for treatment of the flu. Baloxavir marboxil is an antiviral drug like other currently available flu drugs, but it works differently, interfering with the virus’s ability to multiply.

Headline: The better way to discipline children
Summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics advises against the use of aversive discipline techniques, such as spanking or repeatedly yelling at a child, as they can lead to problems later in the child’s life. A more positive and proactive approach to discipline that sets clear limits and has consistent, predictable consequences can work.

Headline: 6 steps toward a successful exercise resolution
Give yourself an annual health self-assessment
Summary: An annual health self-assessment—a full analysis of your well-being—is a way to evaluate your status, taking into account both what you have accomplished and where you may be able to improve.

Headline: Surgeons are doing fewer knee surgeries
Summary: Arthroscopic surgery is very effective for certain knee conditions but less so for others. That didn’t stop orthopedists from recommending them, but based on data from Florida this may be changing.

Headline: Can exercise help conquer addiction?
Summary: As the US contends with the ongoing opioid epidemic, the idea that exercise can help people cope with and ultimately overcome addiction is gaining traction. Exercise helps provide structure and focus, helps treat mental health issues related to substance use, and can bring together individuals with a common goal.

Headline: Does social media make you lonely?
Summary: Do you feel you spend too much time on social media? Does the time you do spend on social media leave you feeling depressed, anxious, or lonely? Being more aware of how much time you spend and how it makes you feel, and taking steps to limit your usage, could leave you feeling better.

Headline: Alcohol use disorder: When is drinking a problem?
Summary: While it may have been overshadowed by the opioid epidemic, alcohol use disorder is at least as common, if perhaps not quite as sensationalized. Many people do not realize that medications and counseling can help people reduce or eliminate their alcohol use.

Headline: Benefits of a healthy diet — with or without weight loss
Summary: Can you improve your health by changing your diet, even if you are unable to lose weight? Three studies examined different variations on the DASH diet, and all found improvements in blood pressure, plus lower LDL cholesterol and triglycerides in one instance — even without weight loss.

Headline: Heart failure and salt: The great debate
Summary: While doctors typically recommend restricting sodium for heart failure patients, a recent review of studies found limited and inconclusive evidence that a low-salt diet makes a difference. But good judgment tells us that avoiding excess salt is good advice for everyone, not just those with heart failure.

Headline: Seasons of grief
Summary: The loss of a family member to death related to a substance use disorder inevitably continues to affect the survivors, altering their relationships with each other and causing celebratory days or events to become new reminders of what has been lost.

Headline: The new exercise guidelines: Any changes for you?
Intimate partner violence and traumatic brain injury: An invisible public health epidemic
Summary: While post-concussive symptoms are common in women who have experienced intimate partner violence, many women hide their symptoms and little research has been done, meaning the long-term health risks of millions of women are unknown.

Headline: Smell disorders: When your sense of smell goes astray
Holiday toys for kids: “Back to basics” is best
Summary: As you are shopping for the children on your gift list this year, it may be tempting to choose the latest shiny gadget, but consider choosing toys for them that encourage learning and development, creativity, imagination, language skills, and physical activity.

Headline: Calm for the holidays
Summary: If the frenzied holiday season is stressing you out, try these tips to ease stress and boost calm. Even if you’re pressed for time, you’ll feel better.

Headline: Gut feelings: How food affects your mood
Creating recovery-friendly workplaces
Summary: Nearly three-quarters of employers say they have been affected by prescription drug misuse among their employees, resulting in lost productivity. Ideas like bringing treatment, counseling, and peer support groups to worksites can help employees feel more valued and invested in their own recovery efforts.

Headline: Coping with infertility during the holidays: Darkness and light
