No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified clinician.  […]

Headline: Vitamin D recommendations
Summary: Vitamin D has been talked about as the vitamin — the one that might help fend off everything from cancer to heart disease to autoimmune disorders, if only we were to get enough of it. “Whoa!” is the message from a committee of experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) to update recommendations for vitamin D (and for calcium). […]

Headline: Laugh and be thankful—it’s good for the heart
Summary: One of the things I like most about Thanksgiving is the laughter around the dinner table. The food is great, make no mistake. But it’s the sounds of happiness—the high peal, the good-natured guffaw, the snort-and-shaking-shoulders, and the deep belly laugh—that really make me give thanks. Laughter isn’t just a way to stay connected with […]

Headline: More on Brain Injury in the NFL
Summary: If you watch football on Thanksgiving, keep the players’ brain health in mind. Alan Schwarz of the NY Times has been a dogged defensive end, in hot pursuit of this story. Read his latest contribution here. He points out that the National Football League (NFL) has been slow to assess penalties on players who take violent […]

Headline: This week from HHP: Health apps, office noise, and hemorrhoid cream for the eyes?
Summary: As usual, Harvard Health Publishing’ writers and editors have been busy covering a range of health topics. Here is a small sampling. To read more, visit us at www.health.harvard.edu. Health apps. Smart phones like the iPhone and Android aren’t just phones. They are also pocket-sized computers capable of running sophisticated applications, or apps. Hundreds of […]

Headline: Using the relaxation response to reduce stress
Summary: ARCHIVED CONTENT: As a service to our readers, Harvard Health Publishing provides access to our library of archived content. Please note the date each article was posted or last reviewed. No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified […]

Headline: Screening for lung cancer with CT scans
Summary: Lung cancer is usually discovered late when it’s difficult to treat and has often spread outside the lung. A reliable screening test to find it at an earlier, more treatable stage would be a legitimate breakthrough—and could potentially save thousands of lives. About 160,000 Americans die each year from lung cancer, which is more than who die from breast, prostate, and […]

Headline: Explosion in diabetes isn’t inevitable
Summary: You can fight diabetes, one step at a time. An alarming new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that one in three Americans could have diabetes by the year 2050. The number is “just” one in ten now, and its price tag of nearly $200 billion per year is already straining […]

Headline: Halloween candy
Summary: Trick or treat? It’s really a rhetorical question. They just want the Halloween candy. Millions of American children will get billions of sugar- and fat-laden treats on Sunday night in a tradition that has its roots in pagan and Christian rituals. It’s fun. The kids are outside, walking. And, gosh, they’re cute in their princess and pirate costumes. But nutritionally and dentally speaking, the […]

Headline: This week from HHP: The science of fright
Summary: Crisp autumn weather, flickering jack-o-lanterns, costumed children trick-or-treating—and a good fright or two—make for a great Halloween. What is it about getting scared by a haunted house, a roller coaster, or a bungee jump that some people find exhilarating and others find downright frightening? It could be how you are wired, writes Dr. Robert Shmerling […]

Headline: Painkillers and drug addiction: An ongoing dilemma
Summary: On October 16, 1846, Dr. John Collins Warren, a renowned surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital, removed a tumor from a printer named Gilbert Abbott. The operation was noteworthy for one reason: Abbott did not scream out in pain, as virtually every surgical patient did in those days. The age of anesthesia was born. A Boston […]

Headline: Why eating slowly may help you feel full faster
Summary: ARCHIVED CONTENT: As a service to our readers, Harvard Health Publishing provides access to our library of archived content. Please note the date each article was posted or last reviewed. No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified […]

Headline: Medical journals: Stop being so passive
Summary: Reading medical journals is the main occupational hazard I face as editor of the Harvard Heart Letter. This task is like parachuting into a desert at high noon—I drop into a barren, colorless landscape and then struggle across dry, soporific terrain. The content isn’t to blame; it is usually interesting, and is sometimes even compelling. […]

Headline: Might a PSA test at age 60 simplify decision-making about screening?
Summary: A Swedish study suggests that a single PSA measurement at age 60 can predict the likelihood that a man will die of prostate cancer by age 85, and that at least half of men no longer need to be screened after age 60. But the study has significant limitations, leaving many experts skeptical.

Headline: Stem cell progress: Turning skin cells into heart cells
Summary: Embryonic stem cell research continues to be a political and legal hot potato that stirs up a lot of emotion and argument. In the meantime, researchers are making some remarkable progress using an alternative stem cell approach called induced pluripotent stem cells, or iPSCs (sometimes that gets  shortened to iPS). An induced pluripotent stem cell is an adult cell, often a skin cell, […]

Headline: Americans lag on exercise
Summary: Only one in six Americans meet recommended targets for physical activity. If you aren’t one of them, identifying your barriers to exercise can help.

Headline: Kiss-kiss CPR: The mouth-to-mouth part may not be needed
Summary: The advice to “keep it simple, stupid”—kiss, kiss—seems to apply to cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). But with CPR, kiss-kiss means no mouth-to-mouth contact. A study published in tomorrow’s Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) adds to the evidence that the old way of doing CPR—alternating chest compressions with blows into the mouth—is needlessly complicated in most cases (there are exceptions, which we will get into below). Instead, this study and others (The New England […]

Headline: Are drugs lurking in your dietary supplements?
Summary: Another day, another safety alert from the FDA that a so-called dietary supplement or natural herbal remedy actually contains a drug. That’s the eighth such warning in the last three months (see FDA warnings). The latest one warns that products marketed as “natural testosterone boosters” or sex enhancers, including Arom-X, 4-AD, Decavol, and Reversitol, contain […]

Headline: 1 in 10 Americans Depressed
Summary: In time for National Depression Screening Day (October 7, 2010) and Mental Illness Awareness Week (October 3-9, 2010), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) published survey data on depressed mood in the United States. The report summarizes responses to a standardized questionnaire administered in 2006 and 2008. The researchers asked 235,067 adults about […]

Headline: Experimental drug seems safe, effective against prostate cancer
Summary: A study published in the journal Lancet found that the experimental drug MDV3100 is both safe and effective for prostate cancer patients with advanced disease that no longer responds to hormone therapy.

Headline: Statins may stop prostate cancer’s return
Summary: A 2010 study finds that statins, a class of drugs taken to lower cholesterol, may prevent prostate cancer from recurring after surgery.

Headline: Naps for young doctors
Summary: Doctors-in-training should be encouraged to do some on-the-job napping, according to the organization that sets the standards for residency programs around the country. The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) issued new standards yesterday that came out in favor of a well-timed snooze. The guidelines, which are scheduled to go into effect next year, say this: Programs must encourage residents to use alertness […]

Headline: Avandia: Fishing with the wrong bait?
Summary: The news yesterday that FDA is putting tighter restrictions on Avandia (rosiglitazone), the diabetes drugs, was important but not surprising. In July, an advisory panel to the agency took a rather dim view of the drug.  Ten of the 32 votes were for increased warnings and tighter restrictions, and 12 were for pulling the drug off the market completely (which is what European regulators decided to […]

Headline: Strong warning on diabetes drug Avandia
Summary: Rosiglitazone (Avandia) should be used only by people who can’t control their diabetes other ways, the FDA said today. Across the Atlantic, the European Medicines Agency ordered rosiglitazone off the market until its maker, GlaxoSmithKline, can supply “convincing data” that there exists a group of people with diabetes for whom the blood-sugar-lowering benefit of taking rosiglitazone […]

Headline: Synthetic biology: Really cool science not yet ready for prime time
Summary: One of the joys of working at Harvard Medical School, at least for those of us who are nerds, is the chance to attend free lectures by scientists who are pushing the boundaries of how we understand the world. So while we usually cover practical health-related topics in this blog, I thought I’d take a […]

Headline: Distinguishing depression from normal adolescent mood swings
Summary: Parents often wonder how to distinguish normal teenage mood swings and rebellions from actual symptoms of depression. I asked Dr. Nadja N. Reilly, a member of the editorial board of the Harvard Mental Health Letter, for some advice on this topic. Dr. Reilly has a particular interest in finding ways to identify and prevent youth […]

Headline: No big whoop: Adult pertussis may not produce the whooping cough
Summary: ARCHIVED CONTENT: As a service to our readers, Harvard Health Publishing provides access to our library of archived content. Please note the date each article was posted or last reviewed. No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified […]

Headline: Those biking Bankers: Active commuters to the World Bank
Summary: After the article on cycling in the August 2010 issue of the Health Letter, we heard from Gary Reid, a public sector management specialist at the World Bank in Washington, D.C. Reid is impressive. He commutes by bicycle 14.5 miles one-way (29 miles round-trip) from his home in McLean, Virginia, to the Bank headquarters, which is a just couple […]

Headline: Eating for prostate health
Summary: Patients frequently ask for a list of foods they can eat to help shield them from prostate cancer. Although some foods have been linked with reduced risk of prostate cancer, the proof of their effectiveness is lacking.

Headline: Advice for dealing with school bullies
Summary: Although adults sometimes dismiss it as a childhood rite of passage, bullying in school is now recognized as a form of aggression that may have long-lasting psychological ramifications — for both victims and perpetrators. Most research on bullying has been done in Australia and Europe, where rates of frequent bullying range from 2% of youths […]

Headline: Prostate cancer vaccine approved by the FDA
Summary: Sipuleucel-T (Provenge), a “vaccine” that uses a patients immune system to fight advanced stage disease, was approved by the FDA in April 2010. The vaccine does not prevent cancer; rather, it helps men with advanced stage, hormone-resistant disease live longer.

Headline: Rethinking when to biopsy
Summary: A prostate cancer diagnosis may send a man to the operating room or drive him to get radiation therapy—even when the cancer is unlikely to spread or cause harm. That’s causing some to wonder when a biopsy should really be done.

Headline: Statins, aspirin may hide prostate cancer
Summary: Research suggests that these drugs could potentially mask changes in a man’s PSA and interfere with the detection of prostate cancer.

Headline: Degarelix approved for advanced prostate cancer
Summary: This injectable form of hormone therapy received FDA approval in December 2008.

Headline: HIFU controls recurrent cancer in short run
Summary: Researchers find that high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) may be effective in treating localized recurrent prostate cancer while also minimizing the chances of side effects.

Headline: Hormone therapy doesn’t seem to raise risk of cardiac death
Summary: Prostate cancer drug treatments that block the activity of hormones have been associated with a higher risk of heart attack and heart disease. But a 2009 study suggests that these drugs may not cause cardiovascular problems after all.

Headline: Statins show no effect on PSA levels
Summary: Ever since the FDA approved the first cholesterol-lowering statin in 1987, use of the drugs has steadily increased, with an estimated 13 million Americans taking them to ward off heart and vascular disease. Recently, statins have gained additional attention, thanks to studies showing the drugs might have anticancer properties. But researchers have inconsistent answers to […]

Headline: Stress and prostatitis
Summary: High levels of stress, poor emotional health, and a lack of social support seem to be linked to a history of prostatitis. Stress also seems to heighten pain associated with the condition.

Headline: Dental fear? Our readers suggest coping techniques.
Summary: ARCHIVED CONTENT: As a service to our readers, Harvard Health Publishing provides access to our library of archived content. Please note the date each article was posted or last reviewed. No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified […]

Headline: Hitch on Cancer
Summary: Thanks to my friend and colleague, Christopher Lovett, PhD, for alerting me to the vivid piece that Christopher Hitchens wrote about his cancer diagnosis. It appears in the September 2010 issue of Vanity Fair. Hitchens is a banality-basher. The value of his piece is in his detailed account — the particularity of his experience comes […]

Headline: Did Lou Gehrig have Lou Gehrig’s Disease?
Summary: Many brain disorders are syndromes where root causes and the neurobiology are poorly understood. Two people can have similar illnesses, but have very different underlying causes.

Headline: Alzheimer’s study on biomarkers generates debate
Summary: A study about a three-protein signature that might help identify people with Alzheimer’s,  published in the August issue of the Archives of Neurology, has generated quite a bit of discussion in the blogosphere.  I thought readers might want to follow the discussion, so I’ve shared some links to representative posts. (We will be covering the […]

Headline: Torn your ACL? Send us your story.
Summary: You may have heard or read about the Swedish study published in The New England Journal of Medicine that found no difference between surgical repair of a torn anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and taking a rehab-only approach. Some of our favorite sports stars here in New England have torn their ACLs recently, including Wes Welker, a receiver for the Patriots, and […]

Headline: Concussions in Football
Summary: I have to applaud today’s editorial in the New York Times that anticipates a new football season. Here is the first paragraph — The millionaire players of professional football are suiting up for the new season with a startling caution on their locker room walls. A poster headlined “CONCUSSION” warns players that lifelong brain damage […]

Headline: Could too much calcium cause heart disease?
Mental illness affects the wallet as well as the brain
Summary: We often report about the psychological toll of mental illness, but while researching a story today I came across a study that documents the economic toll of psychiatric disorders–especially when they are not adequately treated. Researchers at Harvard collaborated with colleagues at the World Health Organization to survey individuals in 19 countries. They found that […]

Headline: Atul Gawande’s latest gem: Hospice care and our end-of-life wishes
Summary: Atul Gawande’s piece about end-of-life care in the Aug. 2 issue of The New Yorker is another gem by the surgeon-writer-health policy wonk and staff member at Harvard-affialiated Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston. In an online chat after the article was published, Gawande said he had the usual preconceived notions about hospice before he started researching the article: Telling a patient […]

Headline: Are crabs and oysters good for your eyes?
Summary: Johns Hopkins researchers have a report in the the journal Opthalmology that sends a mixed  message about whether omega-3 fats protect the eyes. And if you like to eat crab and oysters, enjoy—and we’re with you. But don’t expect any special ophthmalic benefits. Fish and shellfish are natural sources of the omega-3 fats that are believed to pay all kinds […]

Headline: Prostate cancer diagnosis may up suicide risk
Summary: Being diagnosed with prostate cancer may increase a man’s risk of suicide, but more research is needed to fully evaluate the impact of such a diagnosis on mental health.

Headline: Infertility may raise risk of aggressive prostate cancer
Summary: A 2010 study of more than 22,500 California men found that being infertile significantly raised the risk of developing aggressive disease.

Headline: Afraid of the dentist? How do you deal with it?
Summary: In our October issue of the Harvard Mental Health Letter, we offer advice about how to manage dental phobia. I’d love to hear from readers of this blog about what techniques they use to cope with their own dental fear. I’ll compile representative replies in a later post. (This issue is one I grapple with […]

Headline: Unconscious or Subconscious?
Summary: ARCHIVED CONTENT: As a service to our readers, Harvard Health Publishing provides access to our library of archived content. Please note the date each article was posted or last reviewed. No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified clinician.  […]

Headline: Radiation therapy in the spotlight (Part 1 of 2)
Summary: Three experts from Harvard Medical School discuss radiation therapy, its delivery methods, and treatment modalities. Recent advances in radiation therapy and possible side effects are also explored.

Headline: Radiation therapy in the spotlight (Part 2 of 2)
Summary: Three experts from Harvard Medical School continue their discussion about radiation therapy, touching on whether economics and potential profits drive treatment recommendations.

Headline: PSA screening for prostate cancer
Summary: Two studies come to different conclusions about the benefits, leaving patients and their doctors to decide what makes sense.

Headline: PSA — Old controversies, new results
Summary: Many experts believe prostate cancer is the exception to the rule when it comes to screening. In fact, PSA screening may actually do more harm than good. Two studies, one conducted in the U.S. and the other in Europe, were hopefully going to settle the debate over the value of the PSA. While they gave us some answers, we are still a long way from settling the debate.

Headline: Moving beyond PSA
Summary: Genetic biomarkers may help doctors decide whether to perform a biopsy, determine the best treatment, and develop new targeted therapies for prostate cancer.

Headline: Using PSA to determine prognosis
Summary: Renowned radiation oncologist and researcher Anthony D’Amico, M.D., Ph.D. discusses his PSA research and its implications for prostate cancer treatment.

Headline: One couple’s story: Handling prostate cancer in the face of differing biopsies
Summary: Elliot and Elizabeth Boyd share their experience with a prostate cancer diagnosis, explain their next steps in light of seemingly contradictory test results, and offer advice to those coping with their diagnosis and weighing treatment options.

Headline: Raising prostate cancer awareness among African Americans: Two patients’ stories
Summary: Two prostate cancer survivors talk about the importance of prostate cancer education among African Americans and other men at high risk.

Headline: Androgen-independent prostate cancer: A patient’s story
Summary: Ken Gannon talks about his 13 year battle with prostate cancer and his experiences with second-line hormone therapies, investigational drugs, and four clinical trials, one of which nearly killed him.

Headline: A patient’s story: Why one man opted for lifestyle changes instead of treatment
Summary: Patient Ben Hunter explains why he decided to postpone treatment for prostate cancer and the lifestyle changes he made immediately following his diagnosis.

Headline: Choosing — and sticking with — active surveillance: A patient’s story
Summary: Patient Jeffrey Caruso explains why he decided to pursue active surveillance and under what circumstances he would opt to treat his prostate cancer.

Headline: Technology and decision-making: A patient’s story
Summary: How endorectal MRI helped one couple choose the “best” treatment for prostate cancer.

Headline: A patient’s story: Why one man chose robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy
Summary: After talking with numerous medical professionals and asking friends about how they treated their prostate cancers, financial services executive Steve Henley opted to have a robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy. In this interview, he explains what factors went into that decision.

Headline: Drug combo better at easing BPH than either drug alone
Summary: Study shows that taking both dutasteride (Avodart) and tamsulosin (Flomax) might be more effective at easing symptoms than taking just one.

Headline: Continuous vs. intermittent hormone therapy (IHT): No survival difference
Summary: Given the beneficial effects and the lack of a survival difference, intermittent hormone therapy may be a preferred regimen for men with advanced prostate cancer.

Headline: Use caution with selenium supplements
Summary: High levels of selenium in the blood are associated with a slightly higher-than-normal risk of aggressive prostate cancer.

Headline: Hormone therapy: How long should it last?
Summary: A European study finds that mortality is higher among men who pursue hormone therapy for just six months. But the study was conducted in men with relatively large tumors, not small, early-stage tumors, the kind found most often in American men.

Headline: Midlife PSA tests may predict prostate cancer diagnosis up to 25 years later
Summary: According to a 2007 Swedish study, a PSA test done between the ages of 44 and 50 may predict whether or not a man will develop prostate cancer later in life.

Headline: Initial PSA tests can’t distinguish lethal prostate cancers
Summary: In a study of over 250 men, Swedish researchers found that neither the initial PSA level nor its rate of increase in a two-year period predicted which men had lethal versus indolent cancers.

Headline: PSA screening: What doctors tell their patients
Summary: Fifteen Harvard-affiliated physicians discuss their recommendations for PSA screening.

Headline: Task force says no to PSA screening for older men
Summary: The U.S. Preventive Services task force announced in 2008 that doctors should stop testing men who are 75 or older. The panel also concluded that the benefit of screening in younger men is uncertain.

Headline: What does a fluctuating PSA mean?
Summary: If your PSA has varied greatly and biopsies have been negative, you might want to try a different testing regimen.

Headline: Can nerve grafts restore erectile function?
Summary: Studies have shown that some men who have their neurovascular bundles removed during a radical prostatectomy may regain erectile function with nerve grafts. But a patient’s best bet for preserving erectile function is to find an experienced surgeon.

Headline: Treating prostatitis: Any cause for optimism?
Summary: Standard treatments for prostatitis, including antibiotics, anti-inflammatory medications, and alpha blockers, are often ineffective. Patients might find relief by using drugs currently in clinical trials or nontraditional therapies such as biofeedback and myofascial trigger release, a form of massage.

Headline: Prostate cancer risk in African Americans
Summary: African American men have, by far, the highest incidence of prostate cancer in the world. They are also more than twice as likely to die of the disease as white American men. No single factor — diet, obesity, socioeconomic status, or biology — accounts for the disparity, and the search for an explanation continues.

Headline: Blood calcium levels may be linked to prostate cancer death
Summary: Research finds that men with high blood calcium levels are more likely to develop fatal prostate cancer than men with lower blood calcium levels.

Headline: Radical prostatectomy vs. watchful waiting
Summary: Results

Headline: Rapaflo approved for the treatment of BPH
Summary: Men

Headline: No “home run” for proton radiation–at least not yet
Summary: A clinical trial of proton radiation for early prostate cancer found that the treatment is safe and well-tolerated by patients, but probably no better than other, less expensive forms of radiation.

Headline: Radiation therapy may up colon cancer risk
Summary: Men

Headline: What is the difference between PSA and free PSA?
Summary: Kevin R. Loughlin, M.D., M.B.A., director of Urologic Research at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, explains how these tests differ.

Headline: Diabetes inversely related to prostate cancer risk
Summary: Two studies conclude that men with diabetes have a lower risk of prostate cancer than nondiabetics, suggesting a potential biological link between the conditions.

Headline: Second BPH drug reduces prostate cancer risk
Summary: Like finasteride (Proscar), dutasteride (Avodart), a drug used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), may also reduce the risk of prostate cancer.

Headline: Safety concerns prompt labeling change on testosterone gels
Summary: Manufacturers of testosterone gel products must add a boxed warning on the products about adverse effects.

Headline: Vitamin E-selenium-soy combo doesn’t prevent prostate cancer
Summary: Canadian researchers report in 2009 that these supplements offer no benefit in terms of prostate cancer prevention.

Headline: What is a “PSA bounce?”
Summary: I had brachytherapy to treat my prostate cancer and my PSA had dropped to 0.3 ng/ml. But six months ago, my PSA had gone up to 0.5, and now it’s up to 0.8 ng/ml. I’m worried that the cancer is back; my doctor said it could be a “PSA bounce.” What’s that?

Headline: Does frequent ejaculation help ward off prostate cancer?
Summary: Studies

Headline: Can a vasectomy increase prostate cancer risk?
Summary: Experts conclude that there is no association between vasectomy and prostate cancer risk.

Headline: What’s the downside to a biopsy?
Summary: Even if my father takes antibiotics beforehand, could he develop a serious infection when he has a prostate biopsy later this year? Are there other possible complications we should be on the lookout for?

Headline: How soon can I bike after a biopsy?
Summary: I am an avid bicyclist, and I am having a prostate biopsy in a few weeks. How long do I need to wait after the biopsy before I can start biking again?

Headline: What if I have prostate cancer and lymphoma?
Summary: There’s no one correct course of action. In general, experts recommend first treating whichever condition is worse.

Headline: Am I too old to have prostate surgery?
Summary: A radical prostatectomy is a major operation that can lead to serious complications. If a man is older than 75, his doctor may not want to operate on him.

Headline: Do I need to use condoms after prostate surgery?
Summary: Yes. Even if a man doesn’t ejaculate, sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) can still be passed from one partner to another during sexual activity.

Headline: Experimental therapies for prostate cancer
Summary: Androgen deprivation, whether through surgical removal of the testicles or with medication, is an effective treatment for recurring prostate cancer — at least for a while. An improved understanding of the biology of prostate cancer has led to the development of two drugs that might slow disease progression in prostate cancer patients whose disease no longer responds to androgen deprivation.

Headline: Stress and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
Summary: Some evidence suggests that stress reduction may ease symptoms of an enlarged prostate.

Headline: Can radiation therapy combat a rising PSA after surgery?
Summary: I had a radical prostatectomy a year ago and thought I was cured. But now my PSA is rising rapidly, a sign that the cancer is back. Might radiation therapy help?

Headline: Can hormone therapy cause muscle loss?
Summary: I am currently undergoing hormone therapy with leuprolide (Lupron) injections to shrink an enlarged prostate. I believe I’ve noticed some muscle loss. Is this possible?

Headline: Botox for BPH?
Summary: It may sound like a promising approach, but there’s a lot we don’t know about using Botox to treat an enlarged prostate.

Headline: Pomegranate juice may slow prostate cancer progression
Summary: Drinking 8 ounces of pomegranate juice a day may slow disease progression, as measured by PSA.

Headline: Avoiding complications of anti-androgens: A patient’s story
Summary: Sixty-five-year-old George Lincoln* never suspected that anything was wrong. Aside from some of the typical side effects of hormone therapy for his prostate cancer, such as fatigue, occasional hot flashes, mild weight gain, and a loss of libido, he felt okay. He didn’t have abdominal pain, nausea, jaundice, or any other symptoms that might indicate a potentially life-threatening problem.

Headline: When to test for prostate cancer: Finding a balance
Summary: A conversation with Fritz H. Schroder, M.D., the principal investigator of the European Randomized Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer

Headline: Testosterone supplementation after prostate cancer?
Summary: As men age, their testosterone production begins to slow. As men get into their 50s, 60s, and beyond, they may start to have signs and symptoms of low testosterone including reduced sex drive and sense of vitality, erectile dysfunction, decreased energy, lower muscle mass and bone density, and anemia. In some cases, supplemental testosterone may help. However, doctors disagree over the wisdom of prescribing testosterone to prostate cancer survivors.

Headline: Positive surgical margins following radical prostatectomy
Summary: Today, about 10% to 20% of patients who have their prostate surgically removed are told that they have positive surgical margins, meaning some cancer cells may have been left behind. In this roundtable discussion, three Harvard physicians discuss positive surgical margins what patients with positive margins should consider next.

Headline: Is health news helpful or just hype?
Summary: Knowing the basics of scientific research and statistics can help you understand what medical studies really say

Headline: Can prostate cancer be prevented?
Summary: Dr.

Headline: Prostate Health Information
Summary: Welcome! This Web site combines prostate cancer news, expert commentary, relevant clinical findings, updates on important prostate cancer research, and personal case histories to help you fully understand the important considerations in the diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the prostate. We hope you find it useful.

Headline: Preserving penis length after radical prostatectomy
Summary: Researchers

Headline: Questioning hormone therapy as a primary cancer treatment for older men
Summary: Given the possible side effects of hormone therapy, such as bone loss, fractures, diabetes, and heart trouble, clinicians might want to think twice before prescribing hormone therapy as the primary cancer treatment for older men with early-stage disease.

Headline: What is prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN)?
Summary: No consensus exists about what type of medical follow-up is in order for this “precancerous” condition or whether to treat it. Marc B. Garnick, M.D., explains the condition and outlines your options.

Headline: Busy surgeons have better results
Summary: Study shows that patients have fewer complications when prostate surgery is done at a high-volume hospital by a surgeon who performs the operation regularly.

Headline: Experimental drug shows promise against prostate cancer
Summary: An experimental drug may halt the production of male hormones in the body, making it a promising treatment for prostate cancer patients whose tumors have not responded to other therapies. Preliminary studies showed shrinking tumors and drops in PSA levels.

Headline: Onions and garlic may ease BPH symptoms
Summary: Study shows that men with BPH typically eat less garlic and fewer servings of onions per week than those without BPH.

Headline: No difference between drug and placebo in treating chronic prostatitis
Summary: Many urologists prescribe alpha blockers to treat chronic prostatitis, but study shows that one such drug is ineffective in easing the condition.

Headline: Investigational vaccine aids patients with metastatic prostate cancer
Summary: A new prostate cancer vaccine may give hope to men with metastatic prostate cancer by spurring their immune systems to fight the disease, according to a presentation by Iowa researchers at the American Urological Association’s annual meeting in May 2008. Enabling a patient’s immune system to attack cancer cells can improve quality of life and extend survival.

Headline: Data show drug’s benefit in preventing prostate cancer
Summary: Despite previous controversy, researchers report that finasteride may reduce overall disease risk and decrease rate of aggressive tumors.

Headline: Can pathologists accurately and reliably diagnose PIN?
Summary: Study

Headline: Blood test may indicate whether cancer has spread
Summary: Research shows that checking for a protein called endoglin might determine the extent of prostate cancer.

Headline: Drug combo may fight prostate cancer
Summary: Research shows that combining the anti-inflammatory drug celecoxib (Celebrex) and the cholesterol-lowering statin drug atorvastatin (Lipitor) halted the progression of prostate tumors in mice. Investigators are now planning to test the combo in prostate cancer patients.

Headline: Drug may prevent the progression of high-grade PIN to prostate cancer
Summary: Study

Headline: Breast cancer genes pose threat to prostate health, too
Summary: Research shows that men who carry the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are at higher risk of developing prostate cancer than men without the genes.

Headline: Gene combination raises prostate cancer risk
Summary: A Swedish study finds that the combination of five genetic variations increases the risk of developing prostate cancer.

Headline: Urine test accurately diagnoses prostate cancer
Summary: Researchers report that an experimental urine test can better distinguish between prostate cancer and benign conditions than both PSA and PCA3 testing.

Headline: Testosterone supplements of little benefit in older men
Summary: Research has shown that testosterone levels decline as men age. In theory, taking testosterone supplements should counter that natural process. But a Dutch study concluded that they few benefits.

Headline: Testosterone seen unrelated to prostate cancer risk
Summary: A

Headline: Focal therapy for prostate cancer?
Summary: Two teams of researchers suggest that focal therapy may be a promising treatment option for men with cancer confined to the prostate. However, more research is needed to determine its long-term effectiveness.

Headline: Calcium and prostate cancer risk
Summary: Physicians and researchers have long believed that consuming high amounts of calcium and dairy products increases the risk of prostate cancer, although study results have been inconsistent. Two recent studies make clear that the jury is still out.

Headline: Obesity may affect PSA levels, delay cancer diagnosis
Summary: Obese men tend to have lower PSA concentrations than men with healthier weights. As a result, fewer obese men undergo biopsies, potentially leaving prostate cancer undetected.

Headline: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer puts heart at risk
Summary: A study by Boston researchers found that hormone therapy may increase risk of death from heart disease, especially among patients who have had prostate surgery.

Headline: Lycopene and tomatoes: No shield against prostate cancer
Summary: Studies reveal that lycopene, a nutrient found in tomatoes, does not seem to reduce prostate cancer risk.

Headline: Are BPH and LUTS “inexorable consequences of aging”?
Summary: Historically, the answer has been yes, but mounting evidence suggests that lifestyle factors may influence risk.

Headline: How to tell when localized cancer is advancing
Summary: A British study finds that repeat biopsies may play an important role in active surveillance for untreated, localized prostate cancer.

Headline: Anxiety drives some treatment decisions
Summary: Anxiety, not clinical symptoms and disease progression, may sway patients toward treatment.

Headline: Biomarker predicts the development of hormone refractory disease
Summary: Blood and tissue levels of chromogranin A (CgA) may be early indication that prostate cancer that won’t respond for long to hormone therapy.

Headline: BPH drug cleared of causing aggressive tumors
Summary: Study finds that finasteride may actually lower the overall risk of prostate cancer and aid in the detection of aggressive tumors. An earlier study had implicated finasteride in the development of these deadlier tumors.

Headline: Multivitamins and prostate cancer: A new worry?
Summary: A

Headline: Erectile dysfunction drug also may ease BPH symptoms
Summary: More research is needed, but taking tadalafil (Cialis) could be helpful for men with BPH.

Headline: Common genetic variations increase prostate cancer risk
Summary: Researchers have identified several genetic variations that raise prostate cancer risk, variations that may also account for the higher incidence of prostate cancer in African Americans.

Headline: Possible new blood test for prostate cancer
Summary: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine have developed a new blood test for prostate cancer, which in a preliminary study proved better than the PSA test at identifying which men have cancer. The new test measures levels of the protein EPCA-2, which — unlike PSA — is produced almost exclusively by cancerous tissue.

Headline: Do all BPH drugs reduce semen production?
Summary: I have used finasteride (Proscar) to treat my BPH, and it has reduced the size of my prostate. However, my body’s production of semen has diminished, too. Will switching to dutasteride (Avodart) solve that problem?

Headline: Searching PubMed in five easy steps
Summary: You can find and read the studies that are referenced on this Web site by searching PubMed, a resource of the National Library of Medicine. The abstracts (short summaries) of the studies are available for free, but in most cases you will have to pay to obtain the full report.

Headline: Is there a connection between Flomax and cataracts?
Summary: In short, yes. If you take Flomax (tamsulosin), be sure to tell your eye doctor before having cataract surgery.

Headline: Harvard experts discuss surgical options for benign prostatic hyperplasia
Summary: Three doctors describe some surgical options for treating an enlarged prostate, including the ones they think patients prefer.

Headline: Eating for prostate health: Part 2
Post-treatment monitoring
Summary: PSA testing is not merely a prostate cancer screening tool. After treatment, PSA monitoring is the primary method of measuring treatment success and detecting early signs of cancer recurrence.

Headline: The guide to due diligence in early-stage prostate cancer
Summary: In a business, due diligence means doing your homework, exploring all the options, and taking reasonable steps to protect yourself. When trying to make a decision about how to treat early-stage prostate cancer, taking time to conduct due diligence is absolutely vital for three reasons:

Headline: Sex and the Prostate: Overcoming erectile dysfunction when you have prostate disease
Video: Prostate cancer screening not recommended in men over age 75
Summary: An authoritative panel concludes that in older men, the PSA blood test causes more problems than benefits.

Headline: Video: Disappointing results for Vitamin E and selenium supplements
Summary: A randomized trial of over 35,000 men shows that vitamin E and selenium supplements fail to reduce the risk of prostate cancer. In this video, Dr. Anthony Komaroff discusses the findings.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2_b_1_b
Summary: Your PSA level is moderately elevated and increasing at a worrisome rate. Follow-up is needed. However, keep in mind that your risk of prostate cancer still less than 40 percent.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2_b_1_a
Summary: This may be a normal fluctuation in your PSA level. An increase in your PSA of less than 0.75 ng/ml over one year is generally felt to be reassuring. Repeat testing in 3-6 months is a reasonable option. Discuss this with your doctor.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2_b_1
Understanding PSA – I_D_2_b_2
Summary: Knowing your previous PSA levels is helpful, but not necessary. Nonetheless, your PSA level is mildly elevated. Follow-up is needed. Keep in mind that your risk of prostate cancer is still less than 40 percent.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2_b
Summary: The next thing to determine is how fast your PSA levels has been rising. You can figure this out if your PSA was checked within the past year or so. You should subtract your last PSA result from your current results. For example, if your PSA was 4.5 last year and is 5.0 this year, it has increased by 0.5 points (ng/ml) over the past year. A quickly rising PSA is worrisome, while a slowly rising PSA (or PSA level that goes down) is reassuring.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2_a
Summary: Ejaculation or vigorous bicycle riding can cause a small increase in your PSA level. Consider repeating your PSA test in two weeks, after you’ve avoided bicycle riding and intercourse for at least 48 hours. If your repeat PSA level returns to normal (less than four), this is excellent news. If your PSA test remains elevated, further evaluation is probably needed. Your options include:

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_2
Summary: PSA levels can also go up for other reasons. For example, riding a bicycle can put pressure on the prostate and cause a temporary spike in your PSA level. The same is true for ejaculation during sex or masturbation. In general, these activities cause PSA levels to rise only a little, and the PSA should return to normal within several days.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D_1
Summary: Your PSA level may be falsely elevated. This means that although your PSA level is above normal, there is a good chance that you do not have prostate cancer.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_D
Summary: Your PSA level is moderately elevated. About one in three men with a moderately elevated PSA level will be found to have early stage prostate cancer if a biopsy is performed. Early stage prostate cancer rarely causes symptoms, and your prostate may feel totally normal when examined by your doctor (digital rectal exam). One piece of good news is that early stage prostate cancer can often be cured.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_E_2
Summary: Contact your doctor. Your PSA level is high. Your risk of prostate cancer is greater than 50 percent. Immediate follow-up is warranted. Speak to your doctor about referral to a urologist (prostate specialist) or arranging for a prostate biopsy.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_E
Summary: Your PSA level is moderately elevated. More than half of men whose PSA level is ten or above will be found to have prostate cancer if a biopsy is performed.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_C
Summary: Your PSA level is below 4.0 ng/ml. This is generally a reassuring result, and your risk of having prostate cancer is low.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_B
Summary: Your PSA level is in the normal range. This is a reassuring result. You have a low risk of being diagnosed with prostate cancer within the next few years.

Headline: Understanding PSA – I_A
Summary: Your PSA level is very low. This is a reassuring result. You have a very low risk of being diagnosed with prostate cancer within the next few years.

Headline: Understanding PSA – II_A
Summary: Your PSA level is in the normal range. This is a reassuring result.

Headline: Understanding PSA – III_A
Summary: Your PSA level is above four ng/ml. In younger men, this is usually considered to be a worrisome level. However, your PSA level may be normal for someone in your age group.

Headline: Understanding PSA – IV_B
Summary: Your PSA level is in the normal range. This is a reassuring result.

Headline: Understanding PSA – IV_A
Summary: Your PSA level is above the normal range. However, given your age or medical history, further evaluation may or may not be worthwhile. Speak with your doctor about appropriate follow-up.

Headline: Understanding PSA – III
Summary: Next, we need to know your most recent PSA test result. Usually this is a number between 1.0 and 10.0 (PSA is measured in nanograms per milliliter, or ng/ml).

Headline: Understanding PSA – I
Summary: Most doctors recommend waiting until age 50 to start PSA testing. That’s because prostate cancer is uncommon before this age. However, PSA levels are sometimes checked in men younger than age 50 because they have a risk factor for prostate cancer, such as having a close family member with the disease or being African-American (African American men are more likely than other men to develop prostate cancer and can develop an aggressive form of the disease at a young age).

Headline: Understanding PSA – Introduction
Summary: Welcome to this Decision Guide about PSA testing.

Headline: What is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)?
Summary: This imaging technique, which uses a powerful magnet and a computer to generate pictures of the body’s organs and tissues, can be used to diagnose prostate cancer or pinpoint the tumor’s location.

Headline: What is transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS)?
Summary: Transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) can create images of the prostate gland using sound waves. Doctors may recommend TRUS when they suspect prostate cancer based on an abnormal DRE or an elevated PSA.

Headline: Newer screening tests
Summary: Researchers are developing more screening tests for prostate cancer. Like the PSA test, they rely on biomarkers, such as antigens or proteins, which are elevated or may only be present in men who have prostate cancer. The hope is that these newer tests will better detect existing cancers (better sensitivity), and will not raise the alarm for cancer when it is not present (better specificity).

Headline: What is a digital rectal exam (DRE)?
Summary: In this test, the doctor inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum and feels the surface of the prostate to determine whether it is swollen or has any lumps or abnormally textured areas (see Figure 1). This exam also helps doctors screen for diseases of the rectum, such as rectal cancer.

Headline: Prostate cancer
Prostate Cancer Screening
Cancer prevention trial (SELECT) comes to a halt
Summary: The National Cancer Institute discontinued the study after finding evidence that selenium and vitamin E supplements did not prevent prostate cancer.

Headline: Intermittent hormone therapy: A patient’s story
Summary: The jury is still out on whether intermittent hormone therapy, which involves repeated cycles of hormone therapy followed by breaks in treatment, might help patients live longer than continuous hormone therapy. But Patrick Kirby’s story might help patients who are debating various options in hormone therapy.

Headline: Hematospermia demystified
Summary: Spotting blood in your semen can be worrisome, but it’s usually not cause for alarm.

Headline: A Harvard expert shares his thoughts on testosterone-replacement therapy
Summary: Dr. Abraham Morgentaler, an associate professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School and the director of Men’s Health Boston, shares his views on current controversies regarding testosterone-replacement therapy.

Headline: New options for treating erectile dysfunction
Summary: Penile rehabilitation, which typically consists of oral or injected medications, alone or with other interventions, may help restore erectile function after treatment for prostate cancer. However, this therapy remains controversial.

Headline: Erectile dysfunction and heart disease: What’s the connection?
Summary: Even if your doctor has given you a clean bill of health, beware: problems getting or keeping an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse may signal trouble, especially cardiovascular disease, down the road.

Headline: Harvard experts discuss benign prostatic hyperplasia drug treatments
Summary: Three Harvard doctors talk about who needs to be treated for BPH, what medications should be prescribed, and what side effects you need to be aware of.

Headline: Your benign prostatic hyperplasia medication: When to consider a change
Summary: A look at treatment options and trade-offs

Headline: Treating erectile dysfunction with penile implants
Summary: Penile implants, an option patients with erectile dysfunction probably hear little about, might offer a lasting and satisfying “cure.” Abraham Morgentaler, M.D., director of Men’s Health Boston, explains how.

Headline: Strength training exercises
Summary: Regular physical activity can help keep you — and your prostate — healthy

Headline: Eating for prostate health (Part 1 of 2)
Summary: Two registered dietitians from Harvard-affiliated hospitals tout the benefits of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains

Headline: Complementary therapies for prostate disease: What works and what doesn’t
Summary: Harvard

Headline: Outcomes research in prostate disease
Summary: When it comes to prostate cancer and other prostate diseases, how accurate are the statistics we hear? Can patients rely on reported figures to determine their risk of suffering complications such as incontinence and impotence? Why do data vary from one organization to another? Three experts discuss these questions and the growing field of outcomes research.

Headline: Maintaining physical and emotional health during prostate cancer treatment: A patient’s story
Summary: Mr. Williams, a successful business owner in his mid-60s, describes how he was able to maintain his sex life and other aspects of his physical emotional well-being during and after treatment for prostate cancer.

Headline: A patient’s story: Overcoming incontinence
Summary: How one man persisted for almost two years in an effort to remedy one of the most bothersome possible side effects of prostate cancer treatment, and what men facing therapeutic decisions can learn from his experience.

Headline: Androgen-independent prostate cancer
Summary: When cancer advances despite primary hormone therapy

Headline: Answering key clinical questions
Summary: An interview with renowned urology researcher E. David Crawford, M.D., about the state of clinical trials on prostate health

Headline: Promising technologies for the treatment of prostate cancer
Summary: Marc B. Garnick, M.D., provides an overview of possible treatments that need more study, including cryotherapy, HIFU, and focal therapies.

Headline: How to handle a relapse after treatment for prostate cancer
Summary: Marc B. Garnick, M.D., discusses what biochemical recurrence means and what your options are.

Headline: Possible complications of hormone therapy
Summary: Three Harvard-affiliated physicians discuss the impact that hormone therapy can have on bones and cardiovascular health.

Headline: Intermittent hormone therapy for prostate cancer
Summary: Marc B. Garnick, M.D., discusses this therapy, which aims to strike a balance between effective treatment and quality of life.

Headline: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer
Summary: Marc Garnick, M.D., Editor in Chief of the Annual Report on Prostate Diseases, discusses what you need to know about therapy: when it’s used, what your options are, and what doctors disagree about.

Headline: When to consider active surveillance
Summary: Which men are candidates for active surveillance? Some studies suggest that men with low risk cancer should consider active surveillance over traditional treatment, but the evidence is mixed.

Headline: Early-stage prostate cancer: Treat or wait?
Summary: When it comes to early-stage prostate cancer, there is no evidence that one treatment is better than another or that any treatment at all actually prolongs life. If you are diagnosed with early-stage prostate cancer, you’ll want to consider factors such as your values, your quality of life, and the potential side effects of various treatments before making a decision.

Headline: Getting a closer look at prostate cancer with molecular imaging
Summary: Molecular imaging may help determine the location and extent of cancer — and point to the best treatment — especially metastatic cancers too small to be detected by CT or MRI scanning.

Headline: Understanding your prostate pathology report
Summary: Not all pathology reports are created equal. In fact, they can vary widely even within a single institution. Learn what your report should contain, what it means, and why asking questions about it can lead to better care.

Headline: Improved magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may aid detection of prostate cancer
Summary: Dr. Neil Rofsky, of Harvard’s Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, discusses MRI technology, which patients might benefit from it, and the relative advantages and disadvantages of MRI as compared with other imaging modalities.

Headline: Finding help for pelvic pain: A patient’s story
Summary: Patient

Headline: Is fructose bad for you?
